entry.title: Against Intro Stat Classes
entry.content:
Have you ever taken a garden variety introductory statistics course? It goes something like this:

  • Plotting data in various ways, describing it with various numbers
  • Some basic probability, a look at the geometric, binomial, and normal distributions
  • Sampling distributions, the central limit theorem
  • A couple of standard tests for significance and confidence intervals

I have some technical issue with this syllabus. Parameter estimation is worth at least a mention and so are Bayesian methods. Regression is worth a mention, and it does sometimes gets that, although often without appropriate disclaimers. But when a friend of mine took UChicago‚Äôs version of this class, I became aware of a much larger non-technical issue: this class is kind of useless.

More specifically: calculating means and medians are not things you need a class to teach you how to do.Actually, the fact that the median is robust to outliers while the mean is not is one of the most concretely useful things you can get out of such a class, but surely that one nugget is not worth the whole semester-long affair

 The geometric, binomial, and normal distributions are worth knowing about, but doing computations with them is not a life skill. Hypothesis tests are useful mainly if you want to go into the natural or social sciences, but even there, p-values aren‚Äôt what they used to be. Most of these topics justify their place in the course by virtue of being classical, and they certainly are, but I don‚Äôt think you can stand by them as things that are really practical. Unsurprisingly, students taking these classes have no trouble figuring this out. My friend repeatedly asked me questions of the flavors ‚Äúdo people actually use this‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat does this have to do with the work you do.‚Äù Except for a few vague attempts at tracing the line from those topics to more modern areas (e.g.¬†thinking about p-values gets us thinking about multiple testing problems), I came up empty-handed every time.

There‚Äôs a strong and accurate counter-argument to be made here that the things worth learning are not exclusively the useful ones, and that classical material is good to know if only because everyone else does. The problem with this counter-argument though, is that an introductory statistics course is fundamentally different from an introductory course for a major or a specialized elective. It is a course that class almost explicitly bills itself as being useful, and so it could afford to live up to that promise.

What does the fulfillment of that promise actually look like? This is a hard question to which I don‚Äôt have an answer. Part of the difficulty question comes from the fact that different things are useful to different people. Biologists need to know about hypothesis testing. Social scientists need to know about confounding variables. Physicists need to know how to handle uncertainty in measurements. You can‚Äôt give all of them each of these things in one fell swoop without the others crying out that their time is being wasted.

This begs the question though, of how that introductory statistics class lures in people from so many different walks of life in the first place. Clearly they all wanted something from it, and somehow I doubt that something was the specific set of technical tools used in their field. More likely than not, that something is the sex appeal of ‚Äúbig data/predictive analytics/machine learning‚Äù luring them in.

So why not give it to them? Or at least, give them the closest thing there is. The statistics/machine learning distinction is fine and debated to death, but the introductory statistics/machine learning distinction seems pretty clear to me. Everything in the coarse outline I started with is about understanding data or making statements about it. None of it is about making predictions from data, the closest thing machine learning has to unifying principle, and often the exact thing that people find useful.

This is the point in this essay where I should offer a coarse outline of the course I‚Äôm imagining, but I feel dramatically under-qualified to that, so I‚Äôm just going to punt and say that this course seems like a great selection of topics. It‚Äôs probably a little heavy on deep learning for what I‚Äôm imagining, but it definitely has the right thrust.

The statistician John Tukey famously quipped that ‚ÄúThe best thing about being a statistician is that you get to play in everyone else‚Äôs backyard.‚Äù The accuracy of this comment is proof alone that statistics can be useful to everyone. A lot of people end up with piles of data, and wonder what to do with them. The answer to that question isn‚Äôt an introductory statistics course, but I think it can and should be.

entry.title: Information Theory: A Primer
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been curious about information theory for a while now, mainly because of how vaguely mysterious it seemed, and last quarter I finally took a course on it that shed some light. This post is a collection of a few cool things from that course, drawing heavily from the lecture notes linked above, that hopefully gives some idea of what information theory is and why you might care about it. For convenience, I‚Äôm focusing mainly on heuristics and skimping heavily on proofs.

1. The Characters

Information theory, put crudely, studies a handful of useful quantities. In this section, we introduce those quantities and offer some motivation for them. Throughout, we consider a random variable XX taking values in a finite set UU, with density pp so that ‚Ñô(X=x)=p(x)\mathbb{P}(X=x)=p(x) for any x‚ààUx\in U.

1.1. Entropy (and Friends)

We start with the central quantity of information theory, entropy. Note that we write log\log for the base 2 logarithm, not the natural logarithm.

Definition 1. The entropy of a random variable XX is H(X)=‚àëx‚ààUp(x)log1p(x).H(X)=\sum_{x\in U} p(x)\log \frac{1}{p(x)}.

This expression is pretty weird, but it turns out that it captures ‚Äúthe amount of randomness‚Äù in XX. For some intuition (and sanity checking), we turn to a special case.

Example 2. Consider the case when XX takes two values with probabilities pp and 1‚àíp1-p. Then H(X)=plog1p+(1‚àíp)log11‚àíp.H(X)=p\log\frac{1}{p}+(1-p)\log\frac{1}{1-p}. Some easy calculations show that this function is increasing for p<0.5p<0.5, decreasing for p>0.5p>0.5, maximized at p=0.5p=0.5, and 0 at p=0,1p=0, 1. If we imagine XX as the result of a biased coin, this is the intuitively correct behavior for H(X)H(X): the coin is not random at all when p=0,1p=0, 1 (since you know the outcome before flipping it), and is maximally random when p=0.5p=0.5 (since the outcome is equally likely to be either).

The properties of this example generalize to the case of multiple outcomes.

Proposition 3. The entropy H(X)H(X) satisfies 0‚â§H(X)‚â§log|U|.0\leq H(X)\leq \log |U|. Equality is attained on the left when XX takes a single value and on the right when XX is uniform.

Of course, there are plenty of other functions with these properties, and some of them have more straightforward interpretations e.g.¬†the variance. Why this expression for H(X)H(X)? The idea is to imagine that you see the outcome of XX and have to communicate it to another person using a pre-agreed binary code (so each outcome of XX is transmitted as some binary string). If you design the code so that the outcome xx is encoded with log1p(x)\log \frac{1}{p(x)} bits, then the average number of bits you will need is H(X)H(X). Unfortunately, log1p(x)\log \frac{1}{p(x)} may not be an integer, so you have to use ‚åàlog1p(x)‚åâ\lceil \log \frac{1}{p(x)}\rceil instead. This code is called the Shannon code, and has two nice properties.

Proposition 4. For a random variable XX:

  1. The Shannon code takes at most H(X)+1H(X)+1 bits on average to communicate XX
  2. Any code takes at least H(X)H(X) bits on average

So the Shannon code is in some sense the best possible code, and thus the entropy of XX is a measure of how hard it is to communicate XX. This plays nicely with the idea that entropy captures randomness, since more random quantities are harder to communicate.

We can also define the joint entropy of a pair of random variables, H(X,Y)=‚àëx,yp(x,y)log1p(x,y).H(X,Y)=\sum_{x,y} p(x,y)\log \frac{1}{p(x,y)}. More interestingly, we can factor p(x,y)=p(x)p(y‚à£x)p(x,y)=p(x)p(y\mid x) and manipulate this into ‚àëx,yp(x)p(y‚à£x)log1p(x)+‚àëx,yp(x)p(y‚à£x)log1p(y‚à£x).\sum_{x,y} p(x) p(y\mid x) \log\frac{1}{p(x)}+\sum_{x,y} p(x)p(y\mid x)\log\frac{1}{p(y\mid x)}. Then we slightly rearrange to get ‚àëxp(x)log1p(x)‚àëyp(y‚à£x)+‚àëxp(x)‚àëyp(y‚à£x)log1p(y‚à£x).\sum_x p(x) \log \frac{1}{p(x)} \sum_y p(y\mid x)+\sum_x p(x)\sum_y p(y\mid x)\log \frac{1}{p(y\mid x)}. Because ‚àëyp(y‚à£x)=1\sum_y p(y\mid x)=1, the first term is just H(X)H(X). In the second term, each sum over yy is H(Y‚à£X=x)H(Y\mid X=x) i.e.¬†the entropy of the random variable YY conditioned on the event X=xX=x. So we can write the entire term as ùîºx[H(Y‚à£X=x)]\mathbb{E}_x[H(Y\mid X=x)], and this quantity has a name.

Definition 5. The conditional entropy of YY given XX is H(Y‚à£X)=ùîºx[H(Y‚à£X=x)]H(Y\mid X)=\mathbb{E}_x[H(Y\mid X=x)].

Thus we have the chain rule H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y‚à£X).H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y\mid X). Put another way, the number of bits needed to communicate XX and YY is the number of bits needed to communicate XX, plus the average number of bits needed to communicate YY after having communicate XX.

Finally, we could also define the joint entropy of nn random variables, H(X1,‚ãØ,Xn)H(X_1,\cdots, X_n). If we redid the calculation above, the chain rule we would obtain is H(X1,‚ãØ,Xn)=H(X1)+H(X2‚à£X1)+H(X3‚à£X1,X2)+‚ãØ+H(Xn‚à£X1,‚ãØ,Xn‚àí1).H(X_1,\cdots, X_n)=H(X_1)+H(X_2\mid X_1)+H(X_3\mid X_1, X_2)+\cdots +H(X_n\mid X_1,\cdots, X_{n-1}).

1.2. Mutual Information

Suppose we wanted to compare H(Y)H(Y) and H(Y‚à£X)H(Y\mid X). Leaning on our intuition, we would guess that H(Y)‚â•H(Y‚à£X)H(Y)\geq H(Y\mid X), since having already communicated XX can only help us. We can confirm this intuition with an application of Jensen‚Äôs inequality. The deficit in this inequality, H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)H(Y)-H(Y\mid X), is a measure of how much XX reveals about YY.

Definition 6. The mutual information of XX and YY is I(X;Y)=H(Y)‚àíH(Y‚à£X)=H(X)‚àíH(X‚à£Y).I(X;Y)=H(Y)-H(Y\mid X)=H(X)-H(X\mid Y).

A little rearrangement gives I(X;Y)=H(X)+H(Y)‚àíH(X,Y),I(X;Y)=H(X)+H(Y)-H(X,Y), showing that the mutual information is symmetric. s

Example 7. If XX and YY are independent, then I(X;Y)=0I(X;Y)=0 since they carry no information about each other. If X=YX=Y, then I(X;Y)=H(X)I(X;Y)=H(X), since YY carries all the information about XX, and there is H(X)H(X) much of this information.

We can also define a conditional mutual information by taking an expectation similar to the one for conditional entropy.

1.3. KL-Divergence

The last character in our story is the KL-divergence, which is a measure of distance between distributions, but not really.

Definition 8. The KL-divergence between distributions PP and QQ with densities pp and qq respectively, is D(P‚à•Q)=‚àëxp(x)logp(x)q(x).D(P\| Q)=\sum_x p(x) \log \frac{p(x)}{q(x)}.

This sum makes a little more sense written as ‚àëxp(x)log1q(x)‚àí‚àëxp(x)log1p(x).\sum_x p(x)\log \frac{1}{q(x)}-\sum_x p(x)\log \frac{1}{p(x)}. Recalling our discussion of entropy in terms of Shannon codes, the second term is the expected length of a message based on the Shannon code. The first term though, is the expected length of a message if we designed a Shannon code based on QQ instead of PP. The KL-divergence is the difference of these, which is the number of extra bits we use for want of perfect knowledge about the distribution.

Unfortunately, the KL-divergence is not symmetric in P,QP, Q and is not a metric i.e.¬†it does not satisfy the triangle inequality. It does have some nice properties though.

Proposition 9. If P,QP, Q are distributions, and Pn,QnP^n, Q^n are nn-fold product distributions, then:

  1. D(P‚à•Q)‚áîP‚â°QD(P\| Q)\iff P\equiv Q
  2. D(Pn‚à•Qn)=nD(P‚à•Q)D(P^n\| Q^n)=nD(P\|Q)

Example 10. Additionally in many special cases, the divergence simplifies to expressions that are intuitively satisfying.

  1. If PP is any distribution and UU is the uniform distribution, then D(P‚à•U)=H(U)‚àíH(P)D(P\| U)=H(U)-H(P). So the divergence between a distribution and the uniform distribution is just how many fewer bits it takes to communicate a result from that distribution.
  2. If P(X,Y)P(X,Y) is a joint distribution, and P(X)P(Y)P(X)P(Y) is the product of the marginals, then D(P(X,Y)‚à•P(X)P(Y)=I(X;Y)D(P(X,Y)\| P(X)P(Y)= I(X;Y). So the divergence between the joint and the product of the marginals is the mutual information, which measures how independent X,YX, Y are.

And it even plays nicely with other measures of distance between distributions, like the ‚Ñì1\ell^1 distance ‚à•P‚àíQ‚à•1=‚àëx‚ààU|p(x)‚àíq(x)|.\|P-Q\|_1=\sum_{x\in U} |p(x)-q(x)|.

Proposition 11. (Pinsker‚Äôs Inequality) For distributions PP and QQ, we have D(P‚à•Q)‚â•12ln2‚à•P‚àíQ‚à•12.D(P\| Q)\geq \frac{1}{2\ln 2}\| P-Q\|_1^2.

2. Some Applications

Having introduced all the characters, we can get to some plot.

2.1. Sorting Lists

Problem. Given a list of numbers a1,‚ãØ,ana_1,\cdots, a_n, we want to sort the list in increasing order. We can only make comparisons between two of the numbers at a time. Give a lower bound on the number of such comparisons needed.

Suppose that we can sort the list with tt comparisons. To find a lower bound on tt, we consider a random permutation XX of {1,‚ãØ,n}\{1,\cdots, n\} distributed uniformly, so that H(X)=logn!H(X)=\log n!. Now if the true ordering of the aia_i is XX, and we make tt comparisons, the results of those comparisons are given by random variables Y1,‚ãØ,YtY_1,\cdots, Y_t. By hypothesis, we can recover XX from Y1,‚ãØ,YtY_1,\cdots, Y_t, so logn!=H(X)=H(Y1,‚ãØ,Yt)=H(Y1)+H(Y2‚à£Y1)+‚ãØ+H(Yt‚à£Y1,‚ãØYt‚àí1).\log n!=H(X)=H(Y_1,\cdots, Y_t)=H(Y_1)+H(Y_2\mid Y_1)+\cdots +H(Y_t\mid Y_1,\cdots Y_{t-1}). But conditioning reduces entropy, so this is ‚â§H(Y1)+‚ãØ+H(Yt).\leq H(Y_1)+\cdots +H(Y_t). Each YiY_i is takes only two values, so its entropy is at most 1 (we saw this in Example 1). Thus the entire sum is ‚â§t\leq t, and so t‚â•logn!t\geq \log n!.

2.2. Bounding Volumes

Problem. Suppose we have a set PP of points in three-dimensions. There are nxn_x points in the projection of PP onto the yzyz-plane, and ny,nzn_y, n_z are defined similarly. Give an upper bound on the number of points in PP.

In the same vein as the previous problem, choose a point (X,Y,Z)(X,Y,Z) uniformly at random from PP, so H(X,Y,Z)=log|P|H(X,Y,Z)=\log |P|. The key observation is that 2H(X,Y,Z)‚â§H(X,Y)+H(Y,Z)+H(Z,X).2H(X,Y,Z)\leq H(X,Y)+H(Y,Z)+H(Z,X). This can be proven rigorously, but is also intuitively clear: on the right hand side, we communicate each random variable twice across all the pairs, and this must take at least as many bits as communicating all three of them twice.

But (X,Y)(X,Y) is the projection of (X,Y,Z)(X,Y,Z) onto the xyxy-plane, and so is drawn uniformly from the projection of PP onto the xyxy-plane. This means that H(X,Y)‚â§lognzH(X,Y)\leq \log n_z, and similarly for the other two. Putting all this together, 2log|P|=2H(X,Y,Z)‚â§H(X,Y)+H(Y,Z)+H(Z,X)‚â§lognx+logny+lognz2\log |P|=2H(X,Y,Z)\leq H(X,Y)+H(Y,Z)+H(Z,X)\leq \log n_x+\log n_y+\log n_z and so |P|‚â§nxnynz.|P|\leq \sqrt{n_xn_yn_z}.

2.3. Distinguishing Coins

Problem. Consider a coin whose distribution is either PP, where it comes up heads with probability 12‚àíœµ\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon, or QQ, where it comes up heads with probability 12\frac{1}{2}. Give a lower bound on the number of flips mm we need to observe to distinguish the distributions with 90% accuracy.

We‚Äôll need a lemma to do this one.

Lemma 12. For distributions P,QP, Q on a universe UU and a function f:U‚Üí[0,1]f:U\to [0,1], we have |ùîºP[f(x)]‚àíùîºQ[f(x)]|‚â§12‚à•P‚àíQ‚à•1.\left|\mathbb{E}_P [f(x)]-\mathbb{E}_Q[f(x)]\right|\leq \frac{1}{2}\|P-Q\|_1.

Now, getting mm flips means getting a sample (x1,‚ãØ,xm)(x_1,\cdots, x_m) from either PmP^m or QmQ^m (these are product distributions). A classifier TT is a function from this sample (x1,‚ãØ,xm)(x_1,\cdots, x_m) to {0,1}\{0,1\}, where 0 means PP and 1 means QQ. If this classifier is 90% accurate, this means that ‚Ñôx‚ààPm[T(x)=0]‚â•910and‚Ñôx‚ààQm[T(x)=1]‚â•910.\mathbb{P}_{x\in P^m}[T(x)=0]\geq \frac{9}{10}\quad\text{and}\quad \mathbb{P}_{x\in Q^m}[T(x)=1]\geq \frac{9}{10}. Equivalently, ùîºx‚ààPm[T(x)]‚â§110andùîºx‚ààQm[T(x)]‚â•910,\mathbb{E}_{x\in P^m}[T(x)]\leq \frac{1}{10}\quad\text{and}\quad \mathbb{E}_{x\in Q^m}[T(x)]\geq \frac{9}{10}, so ùîºx‚ààPm[T(x)]‚àíùîºx‚ààQm[T(x)]‚â•810.\mathbb{E}_{x\in P^m}[T(x)]- \mathbb{E}_{x\in Q^m}[T(x)]\geq \frac{8}{10}.

Applying our lemma, this implies that ‚à•Pm‚àíQm‚à•1‚â•85.\|P^m-Q^m\|_1\geq \frac{8}{5}. Applying Pinsker‚Äôs inequality we have D(Pm‚à•Qm)‚â•12ln2‚à•P‚àíQ‚à•12‚â•3225ln2.D(P^m\| Q^m)\geq \frac{1}{2\ln 2}\|{P-Q}\|_1^2\geq \frac{32}{25\ln 2}. We saw before that one of the nice properties of the KL-divergence was that D(Pm‚à•Qm)=mD(P‚à•Q)D(P^m\| Q^m)=mD(P\|Q), so we get m‚â•32(25ln2)D(P‚à•Q).m\geq \frac{32}{(25\ln 2)D(P\| Q)}.

It remains to bound D(P‚à•Q)D(P\| Q). We have D(P‚à•Q)=(12‚àíœµ)log(12‚àíœµ12)+(12+œµ)log(12+œµ12)D(P\| Q)= \left(\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon\right)\log\left(\frac{\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon}{\frac{1}{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon\right)\log\left(\frac{\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon}{\frac{1}{2}}\right) This simplifies to 12log(1‚àí4œµ2)+œµlog(1+2œµ1‚àí2œµ).\frac{1}{2}\log(1-4\epsilon^2)+\epsilon \log\left(\frac{1+2\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\right). We don‚Äôt need to be careful here: we can throw out the first term and change base to get that this is ‚â§œµln2ln(1+4œµ1‚àí2œµ)‚â§4œµ2ln2‚ãÖ11‚àíœµ‚â§8œµ2ln2.\leq \frac{\epsilon}{\ln 2} \ln\left(1+\frac{4\epsilon}{1-2\epsilon}\right)\leq \frac{4\epsilon^2}{\ln 2}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\epsilon}\leq \frac{8\epsilon^2}{\ln 2}.

entry.title: Keyboard Phonetics
entry.content:
I was staring at my keyboard a few days ago, and I noticed the facts that (i) the F and V keys are right next to each other (ii) F and V are both the same kind of sound, specifically a fricative. I then noticed a few more: the stops T and D are also nearly adjacent, as are the nasals M and N. This post is an attempt to figure out whether or not all this is a coincidence.

Here is an argument for why it is not a coincidence. To the best of my understanding, the QWERTY keyboard tries to keep pairs of letters that frequently appear together in text apart in the keyboard. Conversely, it must keep letters that rarely occur together in text close in the keyboard. Since you would rarely have the same sound appear twice in a row in any word, letters that make similar sounds should be pushed together.

Here is an argument for why the previous argument is wrong. Letters do not map neatly onto sounds, especially not in English: one letter can make many different sounds, and one sound can come from many different letters. This makes the line from certain sounds not appearing together in spoken words, to certain letters not appearing together in the spellings of those words, to those letters appearing close together on the keyboard tenuous at best and non-existent at worse.

I‚Äôm personally pretty convinced by both of these arguments, so I tried to do something more conclusive. Specifically, I first enlisted a friend of mine who studies linguistics to group the English letters phonetically based on the sounds they typically make.Note that some letters, like C, appear in multiple groups

 The groups she gave me were:

  • Stops: Q, T, P, D, G, K, B, C
  • Semivowels: W, Y, J
  • Vowels: A, E, I, O, U
  • Liquids: R, L
  • Nasals: M, N
  • Fricatives: F, H, S, Z, X, C, V

We can measure how well a keyboard layout keeps each of these groups together by taking the average of the pairwise distances on the keyboard between all the letters in a group. For our purposes, the distance between two keys on the keyboard is just the horizontal distance plus the vertical distance, treating the keys as a grid. So for example, the distance between Q and Z is 2, while the distance between T and J is 3.

Then, we can see if the QWERTY keyboard does an unusually good or bad job keeping these groups together by randomly generating an ensemble of alternative keyboards, computing the average group distance for each of those, and seeing how they compare to QWERTY. Doing this with 100,000 random keyboards gives the following pictureThe different bin numbers are because some of the groups, like nasals, can only have integer values

:

The histogram for each group is the histogram of average group distance across all keyboards in the ensemble. The red line marks the average group distance for the QWERTY keyboard. Based on this, we see that the QWERTY keyboard keeps nasals and fricatives unusually close together, but nothing else. The nasals can be explained by the fact that they are adjacent on QWERTY, and this is as close as it is possible to get. The fricatives are harder to explain. One guess is that the fricatives are the sounds which most uniquely map to letters, and are also least likely to appear together in a word, so they are the most pushed together. But this isn‚Äôt something that I would have guessed before seeing this, and I‚Äôd be interested in hearing other explanations.

One other cute thing you can do is find keyboards that do an especially good job keeping phonetic groups together, like this one:

Or ones that do an especially bad job, like this one:

I‚Äôd be really curious to remap my keys according to these, and see if they make any noticeable difference.

entry.title: Mercer's Theorem and SVMs
entry.content:
In a funny coincidence, this post has the same basic structure as the previous one: proving some technical result, and then looking at an application to machine learning. This time it‚Äôs Mercer‚Äôs theorem from functional analysis, and the kernel trick for SVMs. The proof of Mercer‚Äôs theorem mostly follows Lax‚Äôs Functional Analysis.

1. Mercer‚Äôs Theorem

Consider a real-valued function K(s,t)K(s,t), and the corresponding integral operator ùêä:L2[0,1]‚ÜíL2[0,1]\mathbf{K}: L^2[0,1]\to L^2[0,1] given by (ùêäu)(s)=‚à´01K(s,t)u(t)dt.(\mathbf{K} u)(s)=\int_0^1 K(s,t) u(t)\, dt. We begin with two facts connecting the properties of KK to the properties of ùêä\mathbf{K}.

Proposition 1. If KK is continuous, then ùêä\mathbf{K} is compact.

Proof. Consider a bounded sequence {fn}n=1‚àû‚äÇL2[0,1]\{f_n\}_{n=1}^{\infty} \subset L^2[0,1]. We wish to show that the image of this sequence, {ùêäfn}n=1‚àû\{\mathbf{K} f_n\}_{n=1}^{\infty}, has a convergent subsequence. We show that {ùêäfn}\{\mathbf{K} f_n\} is equicontinuous, and Arzela-Ascoli then gives a uniformly convergent subsequence, which in turns gives that ùêä\mathbf{K} is compact.

Since K(x,y)K(x,y) is continuous, for every œµ>0\epsilon>0, there exists Œ¥>0\delta>0 such that |x‚àíxÃÉ|<Œ¥‚üπ|K(x,y)‚àíK(xÃÉ,y)|‚â§œµ.|x-\tilde{x}|<\delta \implies |K(x,y)-K(\tilde{x}, y)|\leq \epsilon. Then, if |x‚àíxÃÉ|<Œ¥|x-\tilde{x}|<\delta, we have that |ùêäfn(x)‚àíùêäfn(xÃÉ)|=|‚à´01K(x,t)fn(t)dt|‚àí|‚à´01K(xÃÉ,t)fn(t)dt||\mathbf{K} f_n(x)- \mathbf{K} f_n(\tilde{x})| = \left| \int_0^1 K(x, t) f_n(t)\, dt \right| -\left| \int_0^1 K(\tilde{x}, t) f_n(t)\, dt \right| which is bounded by ‚à´01|K(x,t)‚àíK(xÃÉ,t)||fn(t)|dt‚â§œµ‚à´01|fn(t)|dt‚â§œµM,\int_0^1 |K(x,t)-K(\tilde{x},t)| |f_n(t)| \, dt \leq \epsilon \int_0^1 |f_n(t)|\, dt\leq \epsilon M,

where MM is an upper bound on the norm of the fnf_n. The equicontinuity of the ùêäfn\mathbf{K} f_n, and thus the compactness of ùêä\mathbf{K}, follows. ‚óº\blacksquare

Proposition 2. If KK is symmetric, then ùêä\mathbf{K} is self-adjoint.

Proof. We directly compute that ‚ü®ùêäu,v‚ü©=‚à´01‚à´01K(s,t)u(s)v(t)dsdt\langle \mathbf{K} u, v\rangle = \int_0^1\int_0^1 K(s,t)\, u(s) v(t)\, ds\, dt and ‚ü®u,ùêäv‚ü©=‚à´01‚à´01K(t,s)u(s)v(t)dsdt,\langle u, \mathbf{K} v\rangle = \int_0^1\int_0^1 K(t,s)\, u(s) v(t)\, ds\, dt, which will be equal if K(s,t)=K(t,s)K(s,t)=K(t,s), so ùêä\mathbf{K} is self-adjoint in this case. ‚óº\blacksquare

Thus, when KK is continuous and symmetric, the operator ùêä\mathbf{K} is a compact self-adjoint operator, and so we can apply the spectral theorem to find a set of orthonormal eigenfunctions eje_j with real eigenvalues Œ∫j\kappa_j that form a basis for L2[0,1]L^2[0,1]. The following theorem connects KK to these eigenfunctions and eigenvalues in the case where ùêä\mathbf{K} is positive.

Theorem 3 (Mercer). If KK is symmetric and continuous, and the associated operator ùêä\mathbf{K} is positive i.e. ‚ü®ùêäu,u‚ü©‚â•0\langle \mathbf{K} u, u\rangle \geq 0 for all uu, then we can write K(s,t)=‚àëj=1‚àûŒ∫jej(s)ej(t),K(s,t)=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \kappa_j e_j(s)e_j(t), where the Œ∫j\kappa_j and eje_j are the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of ùêä\mathbf{K}.

To prove this, we‚Äôll need a lemma.

Lemma 4. If ùêä\mathbf{K} is positive, then KK is non-negative on the diagonal.

Proof. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that K(r,r)<0K(r,r)<0 for some rr. Choose s,ts,t so close to rr that K(s,t)K(s,t) is negative, and choose uu to be a bump function that is zero except in a small neighborhood around (r,r)(r,r). Then, ‚ü®ùêäu,u‚ü©=‚à´01‚à´01K(s,t)u(t)u(s)dsdt\langle \mathbf{K} u, u\rangle = \int_0^1\int_0^1 K(s,t) u(t) u(s)\, ds \, dt will be negative, contradicting the positivity of ùêä\mathbf{K}.‚óº\blacksquare

Proof of Mercer‚Äôs Theorem. Define a sequence of functions KN(s,t)=‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej(s)ej(t),K_N(s,t)=\sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j(s) e_j(t), and let ùêäN\mathbf{K}_N be the associated sequence of integral operators. We first show that the KNK_N converge uniformly.

The operator ùêä‚àíùêäN\mathbf{K} -\mathbf{K}_N has eigenfunctions eje_j and eigenvalues Œ∫j\kappa_j for j>Nj>N, so it is a positive operator. But then K‚àíKNK-K_N must be non-negative on the diagonal by our lemma, and so K(s,s)‚àí‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej2(s)‚â•0‚üπK(s,s)‚â•‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej2(s)K(s,s)-\sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j^2(s)\geq 0\implies K(s,s)\geq \sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j^2(s) for all NN. Since the sum on the right is always non-negative, it must converge for every ss. This gives point-wise monotone convergence of the sequence of partial sums, which means they converge uniformly in ss.

But now by Cauchy-Schwarz, |‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej(s)ej(t)|‚â§(‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej2(s))1/2(‚àëj=1NŒ∫jej2(t))1/2,\left|\sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j(s) e_j(t)\right| \leq \left(\sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j^2(s)\right)^{1/2}\left(\sum_{j=1}^N \kappa_j e_j^2(t)\right)^{1/2}, and since both of the series on the right converge uniformly, the series on the left does as well.

Let K‚àûK_{\infty} be the limit of the KNK_N. Then, by definition, ùêä\mathbf{K} and ùêä‚àû\mathbf{K}_{\infty} agree on all of the eje_j and their linear combinations, and since the eje_j span the space, this means ùêä\mathbf{K} and ùêä‚àû\mathbf{K}_{\infty} agree everywhere, and so they must be the same operator. But this means they have the same kernel, so K=K‚àûK= K_{\infty}, completing the proof. ‚óº\blacksquare

2. The Kernel Trick

The basic idea of the kernel trick is this: let‚Äôs say you have some data points ùê±1,ùê±2,‚ãØ,ùê±N\mathbf{x}_1, \mathbf{x}_2,\cdots, \mathbf{x}_N. If you want to transform these data points by some map œï\phi, you have to apply œï\phi to all of them, and if you want to run an SVM, you have to compute all N2N^2 dot products œï(ùê±i)‚ãÖœï(ùê±j)\phi(\mathbf{x}_i)\cdot \phi(\mathbf{x}_j). For large NN, this can be a huge pain, so the dream is to choose œï\phi so that you can compute these dot products without actually having to transform the data i.e.¬†find some KK such that œï(ùê±i)‚ãÖœï(ùê±j)=K(ùê±i,ùê±j).\phi(\mathbf{x}_i)\cdot \phi(\mathbf{x}_j)= K(\mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_j).

Mercer‚Äôs theorem allows us to do exactly this, but in the other direction - if we choose KK so that the associated integral operator ùêä\mathbf{K} is positive definite, then we can write K(ùê±i,ùê±j)=‚àëj=1‚àûŒ∫jej(s)ej(t)=‚ü®œï(ùê±i),œï(ùê±j)‚ü©,K(\mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_j)=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \kappa_j e_j(s) e_j(t)= \langle \phi(\mathbf{x}_i), \phi(\mathbf{x}_j)\rangle, where œï:[x1x2‚ãØ]‚Ü¶[Œ∫1ej(x1)Œ∫1ej(x2)‚ãØ].\phi: \left[\begin{array}{ccc} x_1& x_2&\cdots \end{array}\right]\mapsto \left[\begin{array}{ccc} \sqrt{\kappa_1} e_j(x_1)& \sqrt{\kappa_1} e_j(x_2)&\cdots \end{array}\right].

So instead of trying to choose œï\phi so that KK exists, we just choose an appropriate KK, and don‚Äôt even need to think about œï\phi.

entry.title: Avoiding Contour Integration
entry.content:
‚ÄúOne time I boasted, ‚ÄòI can do by other methods any integral anybody else needs contour integration to do.‚Äô So Paul puts up this tremendous damn integral he had obtained by starting out with a complex function that he knew the answer to, taking out the real part of it and leaving only the complex part. He had unwrapped it so it was only possible by contour integration! He was always deflating me like that. He was a very smart fellow.‚Äù
‚Äì Richard Feynman

Partially inspired by this excerpt, I‚Äôve had several conversations in the past few months about doing hard integrals without the residue theorem. I think there‚Äôs a lot of appeal to avoiding such a high-powered tool, so I both like finding solutions that don‚Äôt use it and believe that it‚Äôs usually possible to do so. I got stuck though, on ‚à´0‚àû11+zndz,\int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz, and because this integral is basically equivalent to the reflection formula for the Œì\Gamma function, I thought it would absolutely require some kind of complex analysis to tackle.

I was wrong. The following solution is mostly due to Sameer Kailasa, and evaluates the integral without any complex analysis. It does however, require some pretty technical manipulations, and so to make life easier, I‚Äôm going to ignore all issues of convergence/interchanging limits in this post. The fact that the answer works out correctly means that these issues are actually just technical ones, that can be resolved by appropriately applying dominated convergence/Fubini.

We start by evaluating a particular sum. I know of at least one other way to do this, which involves showing that the RHS and LHS share four properties, and then using these to argue that they agree everywhere, but I like this way better, because the tricks used here is more widely applicable than the trick used in the other argument (in the interest of full disclosure, this means that I know of one other instance where this trick is useful, and no other instances where the other trick is useful).

Proposition 1. We have ‚àëk=1‚àû1x2‚àík2=œÄxcotœÄx‚àí12x2.\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^2-k^2} =\frac{\pi x\cot \pi x -1}{2x^2}.

Proof. The Weirstrass factorization theorem allows us to write sinxx=(1‚àíxœÄ)(1+xœÄ)(1‚àíx2œÄ)(1+x2œÄ)‚ãØ=‚àèk=1‚àû(1‚àíx2kœÄ2).\frac{\sin x}{x} =\left(1-\frac{x}{\pi}\right)\left(1+\frac{x}{\pi}\right)\left(1-\frac{x}{2\pi}\right)\left(1+\frac{x}{2\pi}\right)\cdots =\prod_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(1-\frac{x^2}{k\pi^2}\right). Changing variables by x‚Ü¶œÄxx\mapsto \pi x gives sinœÄxœÄx=‚àèk=1‚àû(1‚àíx2k2)‚üπln(sinœÄx)‚àílnœÄx=‚àëk=1‚àûln(1‚àíx2k2),\frac{\sin \pi x}{\pi x}=\prod_{k=1}^{\infty} \left(1-\frac{x^2}{k^2}\right)\implies \ln(\sin \pi x)-\ln \pi x=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \ln\left(1-\frac{x^2}{k^2}\right), and we differentiate to obtain œÄcotœÄx‚àí1x=‚àëk=1‚àû2xx2‚àík2‚üπ‚àëk=1‚àû1x2‚àík2=œÄxcotœÄx‚àí12x2.\pi \cot \pi x -\frac{1}{x} =\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{2x}{x^2-k^2}\implies \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^2-k^2} =\frac{\pi x\cot \pi x -1}{2x^2}.

Remark. The the factorization theorem is technically a complex analytic tool, but I‚Äôm willing to use it here because a. it‚Äôs really only a technical crutch, not the crux of the argument and b. there‚Äôs no sense (to the best of my knowledge) in which its equivalent to the residue theorem/Cauchy‚Äôs theorem/anything that does integrals. Also, it can be avoided entirely by using the other argument I mentioned above.

Corollary 1. We have ‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)kx2‚àík2=œÄxcscœÄx‚àí12x2.\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{x^2-k^2}=\frac{\pi x \csc \pi x-1}{2x^2}.

Proof. We write ‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)kx2‚àík2=‚àëk even1x2‚àík2‚àí‚àëk odd1x2‚àík2=2‚àëk even1x2‚àík2‚àí‚àëk=1‚àû1x2‚àík2.\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{x^2-k^2}=\sum_{k\text{ even}}\frac{1}{x^2-k^2}-\sum_{k\text{ odd}} \frac{1}{x^2-k^2}=2\sum_{k\text{ even}} \frac{1}{x^2-k^2}-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2-k^2}. The second sum was evaluated in Proposition 1; the first is ‚àëk even1x2‚àík2=‚àëk=1‚àû1x2‚àí4k2=14‚àëk=1‚àû1(x/2)2‚àík2,\sum_{k\text{ even}}\frac{1}{x^2-k^2}=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2-4k^2}=\frac{1}{4}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(x/2)^2-k^2}, and now we can apply Proposition 1 to this sum as well. The result is 2‚ãÖ14‚ãÖœÄx2cotœÄx2‚àí12‚ãÖx24‚àí(œÄxcotœÄx‚àí12x2)=œÄx(cotœÄx2‚àícotœÄx)‚àí12x2.2\cdot \frac{1}{4}\cdot \frac{\pi\frac{x}{2}\cot\frac{\pi x}{2}-1}{2\cdot \frac{x^2}{4}}-\left(\frac{\pi x\cot \pi x-1}{2x^2}\right)=\frac{\pi x\left(\cot \frac{\pi x}{2}-\cot \pi x\right)-1}{2x^2}. Now, noting that cotx2‚àícotx=1+cosxsinx‚àícosxsinx=cscx,\cot \frac{x}{2}-\cot x=\frac{1+\cos x}{\sin x}-\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}=\csc x, allows us to finish.

Now we‚Äôre ready to tackle integral.

Proposition 2. We have ‚à´0‚àû11+zndz=œÄncscœÄn.\int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz=\frac{\pi}{n}\csc \frac{\pi}{n}.

Proof. We start by writing ‚à´0‚àû11+zndz=‚à´0111+zndz+‚à´1‚àû11+zndz,\int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz=\int_0^{1} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz+\int_1^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz, and substituting u=1/zu=1/z in the second integral to give ‚à´0‚àû11+zndz=‚à´0111+zndz+‚à´01zn‚àí21+zndz=‚à´011+zn‚àí21+zndz.\int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz=\int_0^{1} \frac{1}{1+z^n}\, dz+\int_0^{1} \frac{z^{n-2}}{1+z^n}\, dz=\int_0^1\frac{1+z^{n-2}}{1+z^n}\, dz. Since we‚Äôre only dealing with 0<z<10<z<1 now, we expand the denominator as a geometric series, so ‚à´011+zn‚àí21+zndz=‚à´01(1+zn‚àí2)‚àëk=0‚àû(‚àí1)kznkdz=‚àëk=0‚àû(‚àí1)k‚à´01znk+zn(k+1)‚àí2dz,\int_0^1\frac{1+z^{n-2}}{1+z^n}\, dz=\int_0^1 (1+z^{n-2})\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^kz^{nk}\,dz =\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k\int_0^1 z^{nk}+z^{n(k+1)-2}\,dz, and evaluating the integral gives ‚àëk=0‚àû(‚àí1)k(1nk+1+1n(k+1)‚àí1)=‚àëk=0‚àû(‚àí1)knk+1+‚àëk=0‚àû(‚àí1)kn(k+1)‚àí1.\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k\left(\frac{1}{nk+1}+\frac{1}{n(k+1)-1}\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{nk+1}+\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{n(k+1)-1}. Now we tweak things a bit to get 1+‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)knk+1‚àí‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)knk‚àí1=1‚àí2‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)kn2k2‚àí1=1+2n2‚àëk=1‚àû(‚àí1)k1n2‚àík2.1+\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{nk+1}-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{nk-1}=1-2\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^k}{n^2k^2-1}=1+\frac{2}{n^2}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^k}{\frac{1}{n^2}-k^2}. Plugging in the result of Corollary 2 with x=1/nx=1/n now gives 1+2n2‚ãÖœÄ‚ãÖ1ncscœÄn‚àí12‚ãÖ1n2=œÄncscœÄn,1+\frac{2}{n^2}\cdot \frac{\pi \cdot \frac{1}{n}\csc\frac{\pi}{n}-1}{2\cdot \frac{1}{n^2}}=\frac{\pi}{n}\csc \frac{\pi}{n}, as desired.

entry.title: The Limits of Math
entry.content:
‚ÄúThe miracle of the appropriateness of the language of mathematics for the formulation of the laws of physics is a wonderful gift which we neither understand nor deserve. We should be grateful for it and hope that it will remain valid in future research and that it will extend, for better or for worse, to our pleasure, even though perhaps also to our bafflement, to wide branches of learning.‚Äù - Eugene Wigner

I haven‚Äôt done the experiment myself, but I‚Äôd be willing to bet that if you asked people to tell you one thing they know about math, not a mathematical fact, but a thing about math as a field, the overwhelming response you‚Äôd get is that math is useful. This is the answer that protesting high-schoolers hear, and probably also the only thing many of them carry all the way from math class to adulthood. Fundamentally, we think of math as a tool for solving problems in other fields.Which is not to say that this is the point of math - in fact, this misses the point of math almost entirely. But it is the general opinion.

And who can blame us for believing this? For everyone except working mathematicians, math is a tool. Physicists and chemists don‚Äôt care about math; they care about physics and chemistry. But they use math because it is useful in understanding those fields, and the same is true in other cases. How or why is it so useful?

On a basic level, the answer is that it correctly captures certain abstractions about the real world. In the language of word problems, if you have 5 apples and eat 3 of them, the mathematical equation 5-3=2 (that abstracts your apples into numbers!) correctly reflects the relation between how many apples you had, how many you ate, and how many you have now. The correspondence of apples to numbers and arithmetic to consumption is exact.

But this can‚Äôt be the entire story, since there are cases where the correspondence is weaker but the methods are more, not less, powerful. In physics, the abstraction of a moving body to a moving particle, and the resulting reduction of the problem of determining speed given position to the problem of differentiation, contains a string of unrealistic assumptions: physical objects are not points; it isn‚Äôt actually possible to measure a velocity or position exactly at any time; there are forces not accounted for by simple kinematic models. The formal relationship between velocity and position is exclusively formal and even though it has some physical interpretation, that interpretation is not nearly as precise as the literal interpretation of a number of apples. But the predictions of this model e.g.¬†the path taken by a thrown ball, are reasonably accurate, despite the fact that the math no longer matches up exactly.

Maybe the greatest failure of math to match up to the real world, while still succeeding as an analytic tool, is in machine learning. A classic toy problem in this field is automatic recognition of handwritten digits. One approach to this problem might go something like this: each digit corresponds to a set of probabilities on the pixels, where each probability tells you how likely it is that a given pixel will be black in an image of that digit. So if there are 10,000 pixels in the image and 10 digits, all I need to do is for each of the ten digits, estimate these 10,000 probabilities. When you show me a new image, I can look which pixels are black and calculate, for each of the 10 digits, the probability that it is an image of the digit, then guess the most likely one.

The problem is that the act of drawing a handwritten digit has absolutely nothing to do with selecting pixels to color in black. Nevertheless, by playing pretend and working with this mathematical structure, we can correctly identify handwritten digits. Increasingly suspect applications of mathematical tools give only grander results: speech recognition, image categorization, text processing, to name a few.

It‚Äôs not clear at all why math continues to work in these settings, where the abstractions used are inappropriate to the point of irrelevance. It works because it works. This is troubling though, especially because it raises the possibility that eventually it will stop working, and we will be left scratching our heads. More specifically, the putative goal of machine learning as a field is to develop some kind of artificial general intelligence (AGI). But if we don‚Äôt understand why math has been able to facilitate all of the successes of machine learning to date, how do we know it will facilitate AGI?

Let‚Äôs abstract this away a bit: we have a sequence of problems (machine learning tasks), each successively harder than the last, and a tool (math) that has worked on all the problems to date. How do we know the tool will continue to work on new problems (how do we know that the current line of ML research will actually plausibly yield an AGI eventually)?

A reasonable model is to assume that our tool only works on certain kinds of problems, and so we need to decide whether the new problem is of the same kind as the old ones. If it is, we can reasonably hope that our tool will continue to work; if it is not, then maybe our tool was specific to the kinds of problems we had before, and will not give good results on this new problem.

The bad news is that all we‚Äôve done is recast our original question as the new question of defining a ‚Äúkind‚Äù of problems. The good news is that we don‚Äôt have to give a comprehensive answer to this new question - just some criteria for determining when a new problem is of the same kind as old ones. For example, it seems reasonable to believe that if I have a problem, solve it, then move on to considering a generalization or variant of the original problem, that I should expect to tackle this generalization or variant in the same way as the original problem. That is, academically, when one problem in a field points to another through its statement or resolution, it is likely those two problems will be of the same kind.

In some cases, this is a relief. In the essay quoted at the beginning, Wigner mentions uniting quantum theories and relativity as something that may just be mathematically impossible to work out. But the physicists only got to this problem through incremental progress, through one problem pointing to the next, so maybe they can rest easy that they just need to get the math right.I am assuming there‚Äôs no danger of falling of a cliff, so to speak. You can take as many of these steps as you want, and stay within the kind.

Unfortunately, I would argue that this is not the case in machine learning. Although the problem of unifying field theories with gravity in physics is analogous to the problem of developing general AI in machine learning in the sense that they are both major underlying goals for their respective fields, the former problem is very different from the latter in the sense that it was arrived at by repeated pointing of one problem to the next, as opposed to being a goal from the start that is independent of any of the things actually being done in the field.

Abandoning the abstract model for a second, GAI is hard. It is not only hard, but also fundamentally different from all of the problems of image classification and speech recognition being worked on by machine learning researchers today. There is no natural sequence of these problems that leads to GAI, and so it might be a new kind of problem all together. In particular, it may not even be possible with mathematical tools.

This argument is more compelling if we imagine a slightly more sophisticated tool that can give better feedback than just success or failure. If our tool can tell us how suited it is to the problem, we can use this as a thermostat of sorts. Encountering problems to which the tool is increasingly unsuited, tells us we are in danger of venturing out of the kinds of problems the tool can solve. Note that this feedback is not just how hard it was to solve the problem with the tool, since it could be the problems themselves getting harder. This should be the kind of feedback that a toddler gets when ramming a square peg into a circular hole.

In machine learning, where the tool is math, the closest thing there is to this feedback is the elegance of the math being used. And in modern machine learning, the math is not elegant at all. It‚Äôs a mess of matrices and gradients, filled with empirical evidence but no theoretical guarantees. So there‚Äôs an argument to be made that since the math is so messy for these tasks, which are themselves so far removed from GAI, just doing more and more sophisticated math isn‚Äôt going to get us a GAI.

There are certainly counterarguments to this. One is that we can inform our design of machine learning algorithms by human biology, as is the case with neural networks. Then, since we‚Äôre building something that approximates an actual GAI, we should be on the right track. Another is that we basically have no better ideas: all our eggs are in the math basket, and there isn‚Äôt even another basket to start exploring, so we should just plow in.

It‚Äôs because of these counterarguments (and the many impressive results already achieved) that I don‚Äôt want to say that we should only be using math to count apples and abandon it the instant it becomes unrealistic. But I do think we should be aware of the gap between the math we do and the non-mathematical world it models, and especially aware of how realistic our goals are in light of this gap.

entry.title: Thoughts on Live TeX'ing
entry.content:
I decided the summer before coming to college that I wanted to live-TeX notes for my math classes, and dutifully set out to seek advice from the Internet. The results were uncharacteristically disappointing. Only a handful of blog posts and articles discuss the subject, and that handful really only addresses the logistics involved. So this post is a more spiritual take on live-TeX‚Äôing, based on my experiences.

(Caveat emptor: my experiences are probably not universal. Your mileage may vary.)

Before I say anything about TeX‚Äôing, a quick summary of the alternatives. Taking notes on paper, although apparently effective for some people, doesn‚Äôt work for me because of my poor handwriting. Not taking notes, although certainly effective in some situations, doesn‚Äôt seem like a good idea in every situation. So for me, the choice is between TeX‚Äôing, and sitting back and listening.

TeX‚Äôing notes has the advantage of forcing you to pay attention to the superstructure of a lecture. There‚Äôs usually more to a lecture than the union of all the theorems, definitions, and proofs, and typing things like ‚ÄúWe want this to be true in general, but‚Ä¶,‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe punchline is that‚Ä¶,‚Äù or ‚ÄúWith this example in mind, we define‚Ä¶‚Äù quickly draws your attention to them. You could certainly do this with a pen and paper too, but they‚Äôre usually too slow to give you time to jot down these longer ideas (unless that‚Äôs all you do). The speed of typing gives you extra time to spend on exposition, and crafting this exposition on the fly solidifies your ideas about the material.

This advantage is tempered though, by the difficulties that can arise from TeX‚Äôing long technical arguments. One flavor of such arguments, that involves repeated manipulations of a single expression, is very amenable to being TeX‚Äôed ‚Äì copy-pasting is significantly faster than rewriting the entire expression. But another flavor involves many different expressions that hardly resemble each other, and these are deeply problematic, especially if matrices rear their ugly head or if subscripts are floating around. I‚Äôve made the mistake before of getting caught up in transcription, only to realize that I have no clue what the math I‚Äôm transcribing means.

Another issue is that superstructure isn‚Äôt always what you should be paying attention to in a lecture. There‚Äôs a certain kind of wild, edge-of-your-seat lecture, where it‚Äôs all you can do to hang on and follow the speaker line by line. In these talks, trying to suss out those big ideas not only fails, but actually detracts from your ability to understand the basic material. On the other end of the spectrum, some lectures are on material that you‚Äôve seen or are completely familiar with, and have already internalized the yoga of, so this advantage completely evaporates.

A great deal also depends on the lecturer. Obviously good lecturers are easy to take notes on, and bad lecturers hard, but many otherwise insignificant quirks can make a particular lecturer a pain to live-TeX.

Some lecturers are fond of nesting things. They‚Äôll start a theorem, realize they need a definition, make a few remarks about the definition, maybe prove a claim. This is all fine at the board, but if you‚Äôre working (as I often do) with boxes around theorems and definitions on the page, it doesn‚Äôt translate well at all.

Other lecturers are prone to making corrections to their board work that are easy at the board, but hard on a computer. Swapping entries in a large matrix, adding forgotten tildes, or erasing and rewriting part of an expression while verbally explaining the manipulation all fall into this category.

And finally, there are lecturers who draw pictures. Simpler pictures, or complicated pictures drawn once and left alone are usually fine, and can be recreated afterward if they‚Äôre essential, but sometimes you have lectures that basically consist of progressively adding to a single image over the course of an hour, and these are really a lost cause. I have no idea how to handle them.

Of course, it‚Äôs very hard to synthesize all of these ideas into a hard and fast rule for deciding whether or not to TeX a talk. The system I‚Äôve developed is that unless I‚Äôm very confident that it won‚Äôt work out, I‚Äôll err on the side of trying to TeX, but am also very forgiving of myself for giving up halfway through a talk. It‚Äôs not a perfect system, but it gives reasonable results, especially as I become more aware of the red flags that tell me to stop TeX‚Äôing.

entry.title: When Expectations Fail
entry.content:
I‚Äôve seen three examples of the same strange thing happening over the past few months, and I wanted to compile them here. The basic set-up is this: in an optimal stopping problem, we usually have some kind of stochastic process, say on a state space SS, and for each state x‚ààSx\in S, we take f(x)f(x) to be the payoff from stopping at xx and u(x)u(x) to be the expected payoff from continuing from xx. Then, v(x)v(x), the ‚Äúvalue‚Äù of state xx, should be v(x)=max{u(x),f(x)}v(x)=\max\{u(x), f(x)\}. Between stopping and continuing, we pick whichever is better. If they‚Äôre the same, it doesn‚Äôt matter which one we choose.

This formalism is really just a manifestation of the way I think most people think about the kinds of optimal stopping problems they meet in the real world: am I better off stopping or not? But the weird thing I‚Äôve seen is that this strategy can actually give completely counterintuitive and incorrect results. The first time I saw this, I brushed it off as a weird edge case, but then I saw two more such examples.

This is weirdly unsettling, because expected value is (maybe implicitly) held up as this great tool for thinking about how to play little games like this and make decisions, but it clearly has some serious drawbacks that I hadn‚Äôt been fully aware of until seeing these.

1. Three Examples

Consider the secretary problemThis is actually what‚Äôs called the cardinal payoff variant of the problem

, where we see some sequence of nn applicants for a position, each applicant has an associated value measuring their quality, and our payoff is this quality value. We must decide whether to accept/reject an applicant immediately after seeing them, and cannot call them back.

If the qualities of the applicants are drawn from a uniform distribution, then it can be shown that the best strategy is to go through n\sqrt{n} candidates, and then pick the next best one. But if the qualities are drawn from the negative half of the Cauchy distribution, that is, with PDF P(Quality=x)=2œÄ‚ãÖ11+x2,x‚â§0,P(\text{Quality}=x)=\frac{2}{\pi}\cdot \frac{1}{1+x^2},\quad x\leq 0, then strange things happen. In particular, we can check that E(Quality)=2œÄ‚à´‚àí‚àû0x1+x2dx=‚àí‚àû,E(\text{Quality})=\frac{2}{\pi}\int_{-\infty}^0 \frac{x}{1+x^2}\, dx=-\infty, so the expected quality of any applicant is negative infinity! What this means is that when we see the first applicant, the expected payoff from continuing is negative infinity, so we always accept the first candidate we see. But the payoff from using this strategy is the expected quality of the first candidate, which is still negative infinity!

Consider a simple random walk on ‚Ñ§+{\mathbb{Z}}^+ starting at some N>0N>0 with an absorbing boundary i.e.¬†once you reach zero, you stop walking. If we have the payoff function f(n)=n2f(n)=n^2 for stopping at nn, then E(f(Xn+1)‚à£Xn=k)=12(k+1)2+12(k‚àí1)1=k2+1>f(Xn),E(f(X_{n+1})\mid X_n=k)=\frac{1}{2}(k+1)^2+\frac{1}{2}(k-1)^1=k^2+1>f(X_n), so the expected payoff from continuing is always greater than the payoff from stopping. But the walk is recurrent, so if we continue walking for long enough, we are guaranteed to reach 0 and win nothing.

Consider a series of double-or-nothing bets on the results of a flip of a biased coin that comes up heads with probability p>12p>\frac{1}{2}. The expected value of taking the bet when you have NN dollars is p(2N)+(1‚àíp)0=2pN>N,p(2N)+(1-p)0=2pN>N, so we should always take the bet. But the coin will eventually come up tails with probability 1, and we will lose everything.

(Credits: I saw the first example in a Facebook post by Kevin Dong, the second on a problem set for my stochastic processes class, and the third in a conversation with a friend.)

What‚Äôs going on? How did this seemingly foolproof plan of just doing the thing that maximized our expectation go so awry?

2. The Secretary Problem

For the secretary problem, the apparent issue is that having infinite expectations just gives meaningless results. It‚Äôs not too bad when you‚Äôre trying to compare an infinite and finite expectation, because then you can at least say something like ‚Äúwe should do anything to avoid something with infinitely negative expected value,‚Äù but the example here is trying to compare two infinite expectations (the expectation from stopping after one candidate and the expectation from stopping after two candidates), and it all falls apart. The only consolation is that this expected value will never be attained - the first candidate can only be finitely bad, after all.

3. The Random Walk

For the random walk, I think a small computation is helpful. Let‚Äôs say we adopt a strategy where we a set two markers, say at a<N<ba<N<b, and stop whenever we reach them. To compute the expected payoff of such a strategy, let X1,‚ãØ,XnX_1,\cdots, X_n be i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables with parameter p=1/2p=1/2. Then our simple random walk is given by the recurrence Sn=Sn‚àí1+XnS_n=S_{n-1}+X_n with S0=NS_0=N.

We can check that if ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n is the œÉ\sigma-algebra generated by X1,‚ãØ,XnX_1,\cdots, X_n, then SnS_n is measurable with respect to ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n, and furthermore, E(Sn+1‚à£‚Ñ±n)=E(Sn+Xn+1‚à£‚Ñ±n)=E(Sn‚à£‚Ñ±n)+E(Xn+1‚à£‚Ñ±n)=Sn,E(S_{n+1}\mid \mathcal{F}_n)=E(S_{n}+X_{n+1}\mid \mathcal{F}_n)=E(S_n\mid \mathcal{F}_n)+E(X_{n+1}\mid \mathcal{F}_n)=S_n, so SnS_n is a martingale with respect to ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n. Now, if we let T=min{n‚à£Sn=a or Sn=b},T=\min\{n\mid S_n=a\text{ or }S_n=b\}, the optimal stopping theorem gives us E(ST)=E(S0)=NE(S_T)=E(S_0)=N. Then, P(T=a)a+(1‚àíP(T=a))b=N‚üπP(T=a)=N‚àíba‚àíb,P(T=b)=a‚àíNa‚àíb.P(T=a)a+(1-P(T=a))b=N\implies P(T=a)=\frac{N-b}{a-b}, P(T=b)=\frac{a-N}{a-b}. With this in mind, our expected payoff is E(a,b)=a2N‚àíba‚àíb+b2a‚àíNa‚àíb=(a2‚àíb2)N+ab(b‚àía)a‚àíb=N(a+b)‚àíab.E(a,b)=a^2\frac{N-b}{a-b}+b^2\frac{a-N}{a-b}=\frac{(a^2-b^2)N+ab(b-a)}{a-b}=N(a+b)-ab.

The issue is a little clearer now: E(a,b)E(a,b) is linear in both a,ba,b, so it‚Äôs extrema are at the endpointsthat is, we can always do better by making aa smaller or bb larger. This corresponds exactly to the ‚Äúwe‚Äôre always better off taking another step‚Äù mentality that the one step expectation calculation gave, except that now we see that this problem isn‚Äôt just an artifact of only looking one step ahead.

I think what‚Äôs going wrong here is that the expectation isn‚Äôt accounting for the opportunity cost involved. When we take f(Xn+1‚à£Xn=1)f(X_{n+1}\mid X_n=1), the fact that state 0 has zero payoff doesn‚Äôt sufficiently capture the fact that we‚Äôll also lose the opportunity to continue playing. This can also be thought of as a local/global type issue, where the thing that‚Äôs ruining everything is the recurrence of the walk, which is a global property, but our expected value computations are all local.

4. The Coin Game

It makes sense to do a computation similar to the previous one, but the computation is much easier here: if we decide that we‚Äôre going to stop after kk flips, the expected payoff is pk‚ãÖ2k+(1‚àípk)‚ãÖ0=(2p)k.p^k\cdot 2^k+(1-p^k)\cdot 0=(2p)^k. This has the same qualitative behavior as the payoff function from the random walk, where it increases as we play for longer, and we can explain it in the same way, by saying that the expected value doesn‚Äôt realize that the game ends when we flip tails. But this behavior is arising from a different kind of payoff function, so there‚Äôs an underlying structural difference between the two. I‚Äôd be curious to know if there are other examples of games that have such payoff functions, or if these are in some sense the only two ways this can happen.

entry.title: Memory in Speech Processing
entry.content:
This very short post is just to jot down an epiphany I had about a connection between two different approaches used in speech processing.

One popular kind of feature extracted from raw speech data is an MFCC. I don‚Äôt want to dwell too much on what exactly this is, but it basically involves taking two Fourier transforms (so it‚Äôs the spectrum of a spectrum), which works well, but is completely mystifying. The first Fourier transform makes sense, since sound waves are a periodic phenomenon, but the second one makes much less sense.

Another group of approaches that are growing in popularity are recurrent neural networks, which are basically networks that have some notion of ‚Äúmemory‚Äù built in to them. This means that inputs seen at previous times can be used for prediction for a present input, although details vary a lot depending on the particular implementation.

The punchline is that, on some level, these are doing similar things. Or rather, the MFCC is also relying on the idea that data from previous time points are influencing the current data point.

To see this, suppose our data are x1,x2,‚ãØ,x_1, x_2,\cdots, and that they follow a model of the form xt=st+Ast‚àíD,x_t=s_t+As_{t-D},

for some other stationary series sts_t and constants A,DA, D. The recurrent neural network would try to learn that xt‚àíDx_{t-D} carries information about xtx_t (since it is designed to have access to xt‚àíDx_{t-D}. What about the MFCC?

It‚Äôs helpful to directly compute the spectrum, starting with the auto-covariance. If Œ≥s(h)=cov(st+h,st)\gamma_s(h)=\text{cov}(s_{t+h}, s_t) is the auto-covariance of sts_t, then the auto-covariance of xtx_t is Œ≥x(h)=cov(xt+h,xt)=cov(st+h+Ast‚àíD+h,st+Ast‚àíD)\gamma_x(h)=\text{cov}(x_{t+h}, x_t)=\text{cov}(s_{t+h}+As_{t-D+h}, s_t+As_{t-D}) which, because the covariance is bilinear, becomes (1+A2)Œ≥s(h)+AŒ≥s(h+D)+AŒ≥s(h‚àíD).(1+A^2)\gamma_s(h)+A\gamma_s(h+D)+A\gamma_s(h-D).

Then the theoretical spectrum is fx(œâ)=‚àëh=‚àí‚àû‚àûŒ≥x(h)e‚àí2œÄiœâ,f_x(\omega)=\sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty} \gamma_x(h)e^{-2\pi i \omega},

which because of our earlier computation expands to ‚àëh=‚àí‚àû‚àû((1+A2)Œ≥s(h)+AŒ≥s(h+D)+AŒ≥s(h‚àíD))e‚àí2œÄiœâh.\sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty}((1+A^2)\gamma_s(h)+A\gamma_s(h+D)+A\gamma_s(h-D)) e^{-2\pi i \omega h}.

This can be rewritten as (1+A2)fs(œâ)+Ae2œÄiœâD‚àëh=‚àí‚àû‚àûŒ≥s(h+D)e‚àí2œÄiœâ(h+D)+Ae‚àí2œÄiœâD‚àëh=‚àí‚àû‚àûŒ≥s(h‚àíD)e‚àí2œÄiœâ(h‚àíD),(1+A^2)f_s(\omega)+Ae^{2\pi i \omega D}\sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty} \gamma_s(h+D)e^{-2\pi i \omega (h+D)}+Ae^{-2\pi i \omega D}\sum_{h=-\infty}^{\infty} \gamma_s(h-D)e^{-2\pi i \omega (h-D)},

and then simplified to (1+A2)fs(œâ)+Afs(œâ)(e2œÄiœâD+e‚àí2œÄiœâD)=(1+A2+2Acos(2œÄœâD))fs(œâ).(1+A^2)f_s(\omega)+Af_s(\omega)(e^{2\pi i \omega D}+e^{-2\pi i \omega D})=(1+A^2+2A\cos (2\pi \omega D))f_s(\omega).

So the spectrum actually has a periodic component, and taking a second Fourier transform means sussing out this periodicity.

This means then, that MFCCs and recurrent neural networks are actually making similar assumptions about the data, or at least trying to exploit the same kind of structure. I like this similarity, especially because it suggests that thinking about the effect of previously seen data points is the ‚Äúright‚Äù way to think about speech data.

entry.title: Sabermetrics, but for Pool
entry.content:
1. Introduction

I spend a lot of time playing pool during the school year. Unfortunately, I haven‚Äôt had access to pool tables for a while, so I haven‚Äôt been able to play. Since I can‚Äôt actually play pool, I decided instead to work on a problem involving it that occurred to me while playing a game earlier this year.

Some ‚Äúteam‚Äù sports are not really team sports in the sense that what matters is not the total strength of your team, but the strength of your best player. A good example of this is chess: when two people play together, the stronger player can just overrule the weaker player, and so a pair of chess players together is roughly as strong as the stronger player (this isn‚Äôt a perfect model, admittedlyfor example, two grandmasters against a single grandmaster is probably in favor of the two, but this is definitely true when the abilities of the three players are well separated).

Pool is not like this at all though. When you play with another person, you alternate taking shots, and so playing with someone weaker than you can be a substantial handicap (and similarly for playing with someone much stronger than you). Playing with another person then, amounts to taking some mix of your two abilities. In this post, I try to quantify this mix, and ultimately answer the following question:

Question. Consider three players, A,B,CA, B, C, with their skills quantified as sA,sB,sCs_A, s_B, s_C. What kind of condition can be given on sCs_C (in terms of sA,sBs_A, s_B) to guarantee that CC has an advantage over AA and BB combined?

2. Set-Up

Before we can do anything else, we need to develop a reasonable statistical model of how pool works. The key assumption underlying the entire discussion that follows is that there is a fixed probability that a player makes any given shot. This fixed probability will correspond to the quantified skill sAs_A from before. This probability should somehow be weighted by the frequency of shots e.g.¬†never making a shot that only shows up 10%10\% of the time should count less towards this probability than never making a shot that shows up 50%50\% of the time. Put another way, this is meant to be an empirical probability: you could estimate it by playing some large number of games, and measuring the proportion of shots you attempted that you made.

Some comments on this assumption: it‚Äôs pretty unrealistic. In particular, the game becomes much harder as it progresses, because there are less balls available to pocket. Furthermore, it‚Äôs not always in your best interest to pocket a ball. These problems can maybe be addressed by introducing some kind of decay factor or something, but this analysis is involved enough with this assumption that I‚Äôm wary of the complications that arise by relaxing it.

With this set up in mind, let XiX_i be the random variable that is the number of balls a player pockets on turn ii (we assume that each of the XiX_i is independent of the others). The number of balls a player pockets in the first nn turns then, is Sn=X1+‚ãØ+Xn,S_n=X_1+\cdots+X_n, and the player will win the game after NN turns, where N=min{n‚à£Sn‚â•8}N=\min\{n\mid S_n\geq 8\} i.e.¬†once you pocket the seven object balls, and then the eight ball. The way to determine the winner of the match is to compare the values of NN for the player and her opponent, and whoever has the smaller value wins (with equality favoring the player who goes first).

This can also be imagined in the following way: the two players are playing on separate tables, each with eight balls, and counting the number of turns it takes them to clear the table. Whoever does it in fewer turns wins. Underlying this set-up is the assumption of independence between the shots of the two players, which is another unrealistic but unavoidable assumption.

With this set up in mind, here‚Äôs the executive summary of how to answer our question:

  1. Understand the distributions of Xi,Sn,NX_i, S_n, N for a single player

  2. Understand the distribution of Xi,Sn,NX_i, S_n, N for a two-player team

  3. Use the results of (i) and (ii) to give an answer

Let‚Äôs get to it.

1. One Player

Suppose we have a single player with a fixed probability pp of making a shot. Then, each XiX_i is distributed geometrically, so P(Xi=k)=pk(1‚àíp),k=0,1,‚ãØ.P(X_i=k)=p^k(1-p),\quad k=0,1,\cdots.

The next thing to do is look at the distribution of SnS_n. Suppose we had Sn=kS_n=k. This would mean that we had attempted n+kn+k shots, of which nn had failed and kk had succeeded. This argument gives P(Sn=k)=(n+k‚àí1k)(1‚àíp)npk.P(S_n=k)=\binom{n+k-1}{k}(1-p)^np^k.

Finally, we look at NN: ‚Ñô(N=n)=‚Ñô(Sn‚àí1<8,Sn‚â•8)=‚Ñô(Sn‚àí1<8,Xn>7‚àíSn‚àí1)=‚àëj=07‚Ñô(Sn‚àí1=j,Xn>7‚àíj)=‚àëj=07‚Ñô(Sn‚àí1=j)‚Ñô(Xn>7‚àíj),=‚àëj=07(n+j‚àí2j)(1‚àíp)n‚àí1pj‚àëi=8‚àíj‚àûpi(1‚àíp),=p8(1‚àíp)n‚àí1‚àëj=07(n+j‚àí2j).\begin{aligned} {\mathbb{P}}(N=n)&={\mathbb{P}}(S_{n-1}<8, S_n\geq 8)\\ &={\mathbb{P}}(S_{n-1}<8, X_n>7-S_{n-1})\\ &=\sum_{j=0}^7 {\mathbb{P}}(S_{n-1}=j, X_n>7-j)\\ &=\sum_{j=0}^7 {\mathbb{P}}(S_{n-1}=j){\mathbb{P}}(X_n>7-j),\\ &=\sum_{j=0}^7\binom{n+j-2}{j}(1-p)^{n-1}p^j\sum_{i=8-j}^{\infty} p^i(1-p),\\ &=p^8(1-p)^{n-1}\sum_{j=0}^7\binom{n+j-2}{j}. \end{aligned}

This isn‚Äôt pretty, but it‚Äôs tractable. Shown in the margine are the distributions for p=0.25,0.5,0.75p=0.25, 0.5, 0.75, to give some sense of what we‚Äôre looking at. As a sanity check, these have the correct qualitative behavior: higher values of pp correspond to less shots needed to finish.

4. Two Players

Next, we look at a two-player team. Let their fixed probabilities be pp and qq, where the player with probability pp is the first player, and the player with probability qq is the second player. Then, on the first players ithi^{\text{th}} turn and the second players ithi^{\text{th}} turn, the number of balls they pocket are given by random variables X2i‚àí1,Y2iX_{2i-1}, Y_{2i}, where ‚Ñô(X2i‚àí1=k)=pk(1‚àíp)and‚Ñô(Y2i=k)=qk(1‚àíq),k=0,1,‚ãØ.{\mathbb{P}}(X_{2i-1}=k)=p^k(1-p)\quad\text{and}\quad {\mathbb{P}}(Y_{2i}=k)=q^k(1-q),\quad k=0,1,\cdots. (We use two different letters for convenience.)

For the SnS_n, we need to distinguish based on parity: we have S2n‚àí1=X1+Y2+‚ãØ+Y2n‚àí2+X2n‚àí1andS2n=X1+Y2+‚ãØ+X2n‚àí1+Y2n.S_{2n-1}=X_1+Y_2+\cdots+Y_{2n-2}+X_{2n-1}\quad\text{and}\quad S_{2n}=X_1+Y_2+\cdots+X_{2n-1}+Y_{2n}. Computing the distributions of these is a bit trickier this time, but we use a similar method.

Suppose we had S2n‚àí1=kS_{2n-1}=k. For this to happen, we must have made 2n+k‚àí12n+k-1 shots, of which 2n‚àí12n-1 are failures and kk are successes. Of the failures, nn came from the first player, and n‚àí1n-1 came from the second player. We need to count the number of sequences of trials that could give this result.

To do this, suppose that ii of the successes came from the first player, and k‚àíik-i came from the second player. Then, we can biject the valid sequences to ordered pairs of sequences of trials for the first player, and sequences of trials for the second player, by intercalating the two sequences.

From the first player, we have n+in+i shots. The last shot must be a failure, and there are (n+i‚àí1n‚àí1)\binom{n+i-1}{n-1} to arrange the remaining ones. Similarly for the second players shots, we find that there are (n+k‚àíi‚àí2n‚àí2)\binom{n+k-i-2}{n-2} arrangements. Then, for each pair of valid arrangements, we go along the XiX_i till we have a failure; then go along the YiY_i till we have a failure, and so on, to construct a valid sequence of shots that would give S2n‚àí1=kS_{2n-1}=k. The probability of any such sequence is piqk‚àíi(1‚àíp)n(1‚àíq)n‚àí1p^iq^{k-i}(1-p)^n(1-q)^{n-1}.

Using this argument, and allowing ii to vary, gives ‚Ñô(S2n‚àí1=k)=‚àëi=0k(n+i‚àí1n‚àí1)(n+k‚àíi‚àí2n‚àí2)piqk‚àíi(1‚àíp)n(1‚àíq)n‚àí1.{\mathbb{P}}(S_{2n-1}=k)=\sum_{i=0}^k \binom{n+i-1}{n-1}\binom{n+k-i-2}{n-2}p^iq^{k-i}(1-p)^{n}(1-q)^{n-1}. Using an analogous argument for the even case, we find ‚Ñô(S2n=k)=‚àëi=0k(n+i‚àí1n‚àí1)(n+k‚àíi‚àí1n‚àí1)piqk‚àíi(1‚àíp)n(1‚àíq)n‚àí1.{\mathbb{P}}(S_{2n}=k)=\sum_{i=0}^k \binom{n+i-1}{n-1}\binom{n+k-i-1}{n-1}p^iq^{k-i}(1-p)^{n}(1-q)^{n-1}.

As another sanity check, looking at S2S_2 does in fact give the convolution of X1X_1 and Y2Y_2, so everything‚Äôs good.

Remark. When we plug p=qp=q into our formula, we recover the results of the single player section. This gives the identity ‚àëi=0k(i+n‚àí1n‚àí1)(n+k‚àíi‚àí2n‚àí2)=(2n+k‚àí22n‚àí2).\sum_{i=0}^k \binom{i+n-1}{n-1}\binom{n+k-i-2}{n-2}=\binom{2n+k-2}{2n-2}.

Final note before moving on: these formulas fail in the case of k=1k=1, because our counting argument breaks down. In that case though, we just have X1X_1, whose distribution we already know.

Next, we turn to NN. Distinguishing cases based on parity and repeating the arguments of the previous section gives ‚Ñô(N=2n‚àí1)=‚àëj=07‚Ñô(S2n‚àí2=j)p8‚àíjand‚Ñô(N=2n)=‚àëj=07‚Ñô(S2n‚àí1=j)q8‚àíj,{\mathbb{P}}(N=2n-1)=\sum_{j=0}^7 {\mathbb{P}}(S_{2n-2}=j)p^{8-j}\quad\text{and}\quad {\mathbb{P}}(N=2n)=\sum_{j=0}^7 {\mathbb{P}}(S_{2n-1}=j)q^{8-j}, and we could plug in the distribution of SnS_n to get a single expression, but that would take too much space.

entry.content:
These are some notes on the proof that U-statistics are asymptotically normal, mostly drawn from Van der Vaart‚Äôs Asymptotic Statistics but also partially from an appendix of Lehmann‚Äôs Statistical Methods Based on Ranks.

1. What is a U-Statistic?

Consider X1,‚ãØ,XnX_1,\cdots, X_n i.i.d. from some distribution. When we want to estimate a parameter Œ∏=ùîº[f(Xi)]\theta = \mathbb{E}[f(X_i)], we look at f(X1)+‚ãØ+f(Xn)n.\frac{f(X_1)+\cdots +f(X_n)}{n}. This is an unbiased estimate of ùîº[f(Xi)]\mathbb{E}[f(X_i)] and asymptotically normal by the CLT. If we wanted instead to estimate a parameter Œ∏=ùîº[f(Xi,Xj)]\theta = \mathbb{E}[f(X_i, X_j)], we might try something like f(X1,X2)+‚ãØ+f(Xn‚àí1,Xn)n.\frac{f(X_1, X_2)+\cdots + f(X_{n-1}, X_n)}{n}. This doesn‚Äôt quite make sense though: why don‚Äôt we care about f(X1,X3)f(X_1, X_3)? what if f(X1,X2)‚â†f(X2,X1)f(X_1, X_2)\neq f(X_2, X_1)? We can fix these problems by requiring that ff be symmetric and working with U=(n2)‚àí1‚àëi<jf(Xi,Xj)U=\binom{n}{2}^{-1}\sum_{i<j} f(X_i, X_j) instead, but a bigger problem is that the terms of this sum are not independent. This means we cannot directly apply the CLT, and so asymptotic normality is up in the air. This turns out to only be a technical issue though, in the sense that we still have asymptotic normality, but it just requires more effort to show.

2. Asymptotic Normality

The the key idea is to project UU onto things we can apply the CLT to, namely things of the form ‚àëi=1ngi(Xi)\sum_{i=1}^n g_i(X_i). Assume for convenience that Œ∏=0\theta=0.

Proof. We show U^‚àíU\hat{U}-U is orthogonal to any function gj(Xj)g_j(X_j). In this sum, if i‚â†ji\neq j, then Xi,XjX_i, X_j are independent and we get ùîº[ùîº[U‚à£Xi]]=ùîº[U]=0\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}[U\mid X_i]]=\mathbb{E}[U]=0. If i=ji=j, we get ùîº[U‚à£Xj]\mathbb{E}[U\mid X_j]. Thus the entire sum is just ùîº[U‚à£Xj]\mathbb{E}[U\mid X_j].

With this in mind, we compute ùîº[(U‚àíU^)gj(Xj)]=ùîº[ùîº[(U‚àíU^)gj(Xj)‚à£Xj]]=ùîº[ùîº[U‚àíU^‚à£Xj]gj(Xj)].\mathbb{E}[(U-\hat{U})g_j(X_j)]=\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}[(U-\hat{U})g_j(X_j)\mid X_j]]=\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{E}[U-\hat{U}\mid X_j]g_j(X_j)]. Lemma. If T^n\hat{T}_n is the projection of a sequence of mean zero random variables TnT_n onto a linear space SS containing the constants, then var(Tn)var(T^n)‚Üí1‚üπTnvar(Tn)‚àíT^nvar(T^n)‚Üí0,\frac{\text{var}(T_n)}{\text{var}(\hat{T}_n)}\to 1\implies \frac{T_n}{\sqrt{\text{var}(T_n)}}-\frac{\hat{T}_n}{\sqrt{\text{var}(\hat{T}_n)}}\to 0, in probability.

Proof. We actually show convergence in L2L^2, and we do this by showing convergence of the mean and variance. The mean is always zero, so we get that for free. The variance is 2‚àí2cov(Tn,T^n)var(Tn)var(T^n).2-2\frac{\text{cov}(T_n, \hat{T}_n)}{\sqrt{\text{var}(T_n)\text{var}(\hat{T}_n)}}. Combining these, the numerator is var(T^n)\text{var}(\hat{T}_n), and so the entire fraction is var(T^n)var(Tn).\sqrt{\frac{\text{var}(\hat{T}_n)}{\text{var}(T_n)}}. This goes to 1 by hypothesis, so the variance goes to zero, giving the result.

The rest of the proof amounts to checking that U^,U\hat{U}, U satisfy the hypothesis of this lemma by computing their variances. We start with U^\hat{U}.

Consider one term of U^\hat{U}, like ùîº[f(Xi,Xj)‚à£X1=x]\mathbb{E}[f(X_i, X_j)\mid X_1=x]. If i=1i=1 or j=1j=1, this is ùîº[f(x,Xj)]=ùîº[f(Xi,x)]\mathbb{E}[f(x, X_j)]=\mathbb{E}[f(X_i, x)]. Otherwise, it‚Äôs zero (since we assumed that Œ∏=0\theta=0). The first case happens in n‚àí1n-1 terms of the sum defining UU, and there are (n2)\binom{n}{2} total terms, so we get an average of n2\frac{n}{2} terms, each contributing f^(x)=ùîº[(f(x,X2)]\hat{f}(x)=\mathbb{E}[(f(x, X_2)]. Doing this for all the XiX_i, we get U^=2n‚àëi=1nf^(Xi)‚üπvar(U^)=4nvar(f^(X1)).\hat{U} = \frac{2}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{f}(X_i) \implies \text{var}(\hat{U})=\frac{4}{n}\text{var}(\hat{f}(X_1)).

Now we turn to var(U)\text{var}{(U)}. Written explicitly, it is (n2)‚àí2‚àëi,j‚àëk,lcov(f(Xi,Xj),f(Xk,Xl)).\binom{n}{2}^{-2}\sum_{i,j} \sum_{k,l} \text{cov}(f(X_i, X_j), f(X_k, X_l)). entry.title: Conditional Expectation As Projection
entry.content:
This short note gives a geometric perspective on conditional expectation, and a nice application of this fact to regression.

1. Conditional Expectation as Projection

Theorem 1. Let (Œ©,‚Ñ±,‚Ñô)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P}) be a probability space, let ‚Ñ±ÃÉ‚äÇ‚Ñ±\tilde{\mathcal{F}}\subset \mathcal{F} be a sub œÉ\sigma-algebra of ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}, and let XX be an L2L^2 random variable. Then ùîº(X‚à£FÃÉ)\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{F}) is the projection of X‚ààL2(‚Ñ±)X\in L^2(\mathcal{F}) onto L2(FÀú)L^2(\widetilde{F}).

Before we prove this, let‚Äôs set the measure theory aside for a second and think intuitively: a common way to introduce conditional expectation without measure theory is to call it ‚Äúthe best guess you would make for XX given some information.‚Äù With this in mind, it makes sense that the conditional expectation would be the point in the information you have that is ‚Äúclosest‚Äù to XX. But the nice thing is that this isn‚Äôt just a cute analogy it‚Äôs a precise fact.

Proof. The norm in L2(Œ©)L^2(\Omega) is the square integral, so it‚Äôs sufficient to show that $$\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{F})=\argmin_{Y} \mathbb{E}(X-Y)^2.$$ To do this, we‚Äôll need a lemma.

Lemma 2. If Z‚ààL2(FÀú)Z\in L^2(\widetilde{F}), then ùîº(Z(X‚àíùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)))=0.\mathbb{E}(Z(X-\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{\mathcal{F}})))=0.

Proof. By Cauchy-Schwarz, ZX‚ààL1(Œ©)ZX\in L^1(\Omega), so we have Zùîº(X‚à£FÃÉ)=ùîº(ZX‚à£FÃÉ)‚üπùîº(Zùîº(X‚à£FÃÉ))=ùîº(ùîº(ZX‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ))=ùîº(ZX),Z\mathbb{E}(X\mid\tilde{F})=\mathbb{E}(ZX\mid \tilde{F})\implies \mathbb{E}(Z\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{F}))=\mathbb{E}(\mathbb{E}(ZX\mid\tilde{\mathcal{F}}))=\mathbb{E}(ZX), and then subtracting gives the result.

With this lemma in hand, take some Y‚ààL2(‚Ñ±ÃÉ)Y\in L^2(\tilde{\mathcal{F}}). Then, we have ùîº((X‚àíY)2)=ùîº((X‚àíùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)+ùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)‚àíY)2),\mathbb{E}((X-Y)^2)=\mathbb{E}((X-\mathbb{E}(X\mid\tilde{\mathcal{F}})+\mathbb{E}(X\mid\tilde{\mathcal{F}})-Y)^2), and expanding this gives ùîº((X‚àíùîº(X‚à£FÃÉ))2)+2ùîº([X‚àíùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)][ùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)‚àíY])+ùîº((ùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)‚àíY)2).\mathbb{E}((X-\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{F}))^2)+ 2\mathbb{E}([X-\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{\mathcal{F}})][\mathbb{E}(X\mid\tilde{\mathcal{F}})-Y])+\mathbb{E}((\mathbb{E}(X\mid\tilde{\mathcal{F}})-Y)^2). The cross-term vanishes because of our lemma. The first term does not depend on YY. The second is clearly always positive, and is zero when Y=ùîº(X‚à£‚Ñ±ÃÉ)Y=\mathbb{E}(X\mid \tilde{\mathcal{F}}), so this must be the minimum. The result follows.

2. Regression

This new paradigm has at least one nice application: understanding linear regression better.

Suppose you have some data points that are generated from jointly distributed random variables XX and YY, which satisfy Y=Œ±X+Œ≤Y=\alpha X+\beta, where Œ±,Œ≤\alpha, \beta are constants. We observe a bunch of data from this distribution, (ùê±1,y1),‚ãØ,(ùê±n,yn)(\mathbf{x}_1, y_1),\cdots, (\mathbf{x}_n, y_n), where yi=aùê±i+b+ùîºpsilony_i=a\mathbf{x}_i+b+\mathbb{E}psilon and ùîºpsilon‚àºN(0,1)\mathbb{E}psilon\sim N(0,1) is Gaussian noise.

We call ùîº(Y‚à£X)=Œ±X+Œ≤\mathbb{E}(Y\mid X)=\alpha X+\beta the true regression function, both because it is the true function and because a direct computation gives that it is the function that minimized the expected squared error of a future prediction. In practice, we don‚Äôt know the distributions of X,YX, Y, so we have to approximate the true regression function with an empirical regression function, ùîº(Y‚à£X)ÀÜ=aX+b\widehat{\mathbb{E}(Y\mid X)}=aX+b.

To approximate the true regression function with the data, we want to approximate the projection of YY onto the œÉ\sigma-algebra generated by XX. But we have no idea what this œÉ\sigma-algebra looks like, except that it contains the data points we saw, so we just consider the space consisting of those data points instead. Then, the approximate projection will be found by choosing a,ba, b to minimize the L2L^2 distance between our empirical regression function and the approximate yy-values (we use these because we don‚Äôt know the exact yy-values). This means choosing a,ba,b to minimize ‚àëi=1n(aùê±i+b‚àíyi)2.\sum_{i=1}^n (a\mathbf{x}_i+b-y_i)^2.

But this is exactly the same as linear least squares regression. The fact that taking this statistical perspective about regression gives the same result as just deciding to minimize the sum of the squares (which can be derived in other ways as well) is not a coincidence, but rather a consequence of the fact that conditional expectations are also projections.
