entry.title: Multiple Testing Procedures
entry.content:
Here‚Äôs something problematic: let‚Äôs say you run a hypothesis test at a significance level of Œ±=0.05\alpha=0.05. Then, assuming you ran the test correctly and met assumptions, the probability of a type I error is only 5%. But if you instead run 100 tests at a significance level of Œ±=0.05\alpha=0.05, the probability of making at least one type I error soars to 1‚àí(1‚àí0.05)100‚âà99%,1-(1-0.05)^{100}\approx 99\%, and this only gets worse as you run increasingly many tests. This is the multiple testing problem, and this blog post discusses a couple of solutions to it as well as why they work. Most of this is taken from my notes for UChicago‚Äôs STAT 278, which I‚Äôd highly recommend to anyone interested in these sorts of things.

The set up for the rest of this post is as follows. We have p-values p1,‚ãØ,pnp_1,\cdots, p_n that we‚Äôve acquired from some hypothesis tests. Some of these come from true null hypotheses, and are distributed uniformly on [0,1][0,1]. The rest come from false null hypotheses, and we know nothing about their distribution.

We want to run a test that will have a significance level of Œ±\alpha, not for each test individually, but for all of them together. This will turn out to mean different things for different methods.

1. Bonferroni Correction

This is a method for testing the global null hypothesis, which is the hypothesis that all of the null hypotheses that generated our p-values are true (so we take the intersection of the relevant events). We do this in the most naive way possible, and it turns out to work.

We just test each of the pip_i at a significance level of Œ±/n\alpha/n, and reject the global null if any of the pip_i are rejected. That is, we reject the global null if pi‚â§Œ±/np_i\leq \alpha/n for some ii and fail to reject otherwise.

In what sense does this work?

Proposition 1. When testing the global null hypothesis using Bonferroni correction, the probability of making a type I error is ‚â§Œ±\leq\alpha.

Proof. This is direct. The probability that we reject the global null is ‚Ñô(min1‚â§i‚â§npi‚â§Œ±n)=‚Ñô(‚ãÉi=1n{pi‚â§Œ±n}),\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{1\leq i\leq n} p_i\leq \frac{\alpha}{n}\right)=\mathbb{P}\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n \left\{p_i\leq \frac{\alpha}{n}\right\}\right), which by the union bound is ‚â§‚àëi=1n‚Ñô(pi‚â§Œ±n)=n‚ãÖŒ±n=Œ±,\leq \sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb{P}\left(p_i\leq \frac{\alpha}{n}\right)=n\cdot \frac{\alpha}{n}=\alpha, so we have FWER control. ‚óº\blacksquare

So that‚Äôs nice. But it‚Äôs also extremely conservative, and we can afford to do things that are a bit more powerful.

2. Simes‚Äô Test

Here we‚Äôre also testing the global null, but a bit more cleverly. The Simes‚Äô test rejects the global null if there is 1 p-value that is ‚â§Œ±n\leq \frac{\alpha}{n}, or 2 p-values that are ‚â§2Œ±n\leq \frac{2\alpha}{n}, or in general, if there are kk p-values that are ‚â§kŒ±n\leq \frac{k\alpha}{n} for any 1‚â§k‚â§n1\leq k\leq n. This will reject when Bonferroni rejects, but also in some other cases, so its more powerful. This power costs something, though: we need an assumption of independence to get a bound, and this bound isn‚Äôt as strong as for Bonferroni.

Proposition 2. If the p-values are independent, then when testing the global null hypothesis using Simes‚Äô test, the probability of making a type I error is ‚â§Œ±Hn‚âàŒ±logn\leq\alpha H_n\approx \alpha \log n.

We assign a score to each pp-value that measures what percent of the way it gets us to rejecting the global null. Let si=1 if pi‚â§Œ±n,si=12 if Œ±n‚â§pi‚â§2Œ±ns_i = 1\text{ if } p_i\leq \frac{\alpha}{n},\quad s_i=\frac{1}{2}\text{ if } \frac{\alpha}{n}\leq p_i\leq \frac{2\alpha}{n} and so on up to si=1n if Œ±(n‚àí1)n‚â§pi‚â§Œ±,si=0 if pi>Œ±.s_i = \frac{1}{n}\text{ if } \frac{\alpha(n-1)}{n}\leq p_i\leq \alpha,\quad s_i=0\text{ if } p_i>\alpha.

Then, Simes rejects if and only if, for some kk, there are kk pip_i‚Äôs that are ‚â§kŒ±n\leq \frac{k\alpha }{n}, which means that the sum of the sis_i is ‚â•1\geq 1. So now we can calculate the probability of that happening.

The expected value of any given score is ùîº[si]=1‚ãÖŒ±n+‚ãØ+1n‚ãÖŒ±n=Œ±nHn.\mathbb{E}[s_i]=1\cdot \frac{\alpha}{n}+\cdots +\frac{1}{n}\cdot \frac{\alpha}{n}=\frac{\alpha}{n}H_n. Then, ‚Ñô(Simes rejects)‚â§‚Ñô(‚àëi=1msi‚â•1)‚â§ùîº[‚àëi=1nsi]=n‚ãÖŒ±nHn=Œ±Hn.‚óº\mathbb{P}(\text{Simes rejects})\leq \mathbb{P}\left(\sum_{i=1}^m s_i\geq 1\right)\leq \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{i=1}^n s_i\right] =n\cdot \frac{\alpha}{n}H_n =\alpha H_n.\blacksquare

Note that for large nn, the logn\log n factor counts a lot, and the bound is sharp. The equality construction is a bit of a pain, but the idea is to choose the joint distribution of the pip_i to make them negatively dependent.

3. Holm-Bonferroni

This test is different from the previous two in that it does not test the global null, but instead individually tests each of the pip_i and then controls the family-wise error rate (FWER), which is the probability of making at least one type I error across all the p-values. As an added bonus, we can accept/reject individual p-values rather than accepting/rejecting them all at once, so we have a much better sense of how significant the results are, taken together.

The idea of Holm-Bonferroni is to run Bonferroni until acceptance. We first run Bonferroni on p1,‚ãØ,pnp_1,\cdots, p_n. If we do not reject the global null, we stop. If we do, then we reject the smallest p-value, and repeat this procedure with the other p-values, continuing until we do not reject the global null.

Equivalently, if we order the p-values as p(1),‚ãØ,p(n)p_{(1)},\cdots, p_{(n)}, this is the same as checking if p(k)‚â§Œ±n+k‚àí1p_{(k)}\leq \frac{\alpha}{n+k-1} for each k=1,‚ãØ,nk=1,\cdots, n and rejecting all the p-values before the first kk that fails this test.

Proposition 3. For Holm-Bonferroni, we have FWER‚â§Œ±\text{FWER}\leq \alpha.

Let n0=# of nullsn_0=\#\text{ of nulls}. Then ‚Ñô(minnulls i‚â§Œ±n0)‚â§Œ±,\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{\text{nulls }i} \leq \frac{\alpha}{n_0}\right)\leq \alpha, from a union bound. In this case, we might have false rejections, but this only happens Œ±\alpha of the time. So we show that the other 1‚àíŒ±1-\alpha of the time, there are no false rejections.

Suppose pi>Œ±n0p_i>\frac{\alpha}{n_0} for all nulls ii. Then, take the ordered pp-values p(1),‚ãØ,p(n)p_{(1)},\cdots, p_{(n)}. Let p(k)p_{(k)} be the first pp-value that comes from a null. We know that this pp-value can‚Äôt be too small, and we know it can‚Äôt happen super late in the list, because there are at most n‚àín0n-n_0 non-nulls. This means that k‚â§n‚àín0+1k\leq n-n_0+1. There are two cases now: the procedure stops before step kk (which means no false rejections because no nulls before kk). Or, it gets to step kk, and we check if p(k)‚â§Œ±n+1‚àíkp_{(k)}\leq \frac{\alpha}{n+1-k}. But we know that p(k)>Œ±n0p_{(k)}>\frac{\alpha}{n_0} and k‚â§n‚àín0+1k\leq n-n_0+1, so the Œ±n+1‚àík‚â§Œ±n0\frac{\alpha}{n+1-k}\leq \frac{\alpha}{n_0}. By our assumption on the null pip_i then, we stop at step kk, and there are no false rejections. ‚óº\blacksquare

As with the Bonferroni correction, we don‚Äôt need any assumptions of independence.

4. Benjamini-Hochberg

This is another multiple testing procedure, but instead of controlling the FWER, it controls FDR=ùîº[# null p-values rejected# p-values rejected],\text{FDR}=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\#\text{ null p-values rejected}}{\#\text{ p-values rejected}}\right], the false discovery rate. The quantity we‚Äôre taking the expectation of is the false discovery proportion (FDP).

Here, we build on Simes‚Äô test by running Simes‚Äô, and then rejecting those kk p-values that are ‚â§Œ±kn\leq \alpha\frac{k}{n}, for the maximum kk we can do this for. Equivalently, we choose some threshold Œ±kn\alpha\frac{k}{n}, and then reject all the p-values below this threshold.

Proposition 4. If the p-values are independent, the Benjamin-Hochberg gives FDR=Œ±n0n‚â§Œ±\text{FDR}=\alpha\frac{n_0}{n}\leq \alpha.

Proof. Suppose we make k^\hat{k} rejections, so our threshold is Œ±k^n\alpha\frac{\hat{k}}{n}, meaning that pip_i is rejected iff pi‚â§Œ±k^np_i\leq \alpha\frac{\hat{k}}{n}. The trouble is that here, the RHS also depends on pip_i, so we have to go through some gymnastics to get around this.

Let k^i\hat{k}_i be the largest kk such that there are k‚àí1k-1 many p-values pjp_j with j‚â†ij\neq i that are ‚â§Œ±kn\leq \alpha\frac{k}{n}. Call this statement the BHi\text{BH}_i statement, and the statement that there are kk many p-values ‚â§Œ±kn\leq \alpha\frac{k}{n} the BH statement.‚óº\blacksquare

Claim. If pip_i is rejected, then k^=k^i\hat{k}=\hat{k}_i.

Call the first statement the BH statement, and the second one (with k‚àí1k-1) the BHi_\text{i} statement.

Now, suppose pip_i is rejected. Then pi‚â§Œ±kn,p_i \leq \alpha \frac{k}{n}, and BH holds for k=k^k=\hat{k}, so there are k^‚àí1\hat{k}-1 of the pjp_j, j‚â†ij\neq i, that are also ‚â§Œ±k^n\leq \alpha \frac{\hat{k}}{n}. Thus BHi_{\text{i}} holds for k=k^k=\hat{k}, and so k^i‚â•k^\hat{k}_i\geq \hat{k}.

On the other hand, pi‚â§Œ±k^n‚â§Œ±k^inp_i\leq \alpha \frac{\hat{k}}{n}\leq \alpha \frac{\hat{k}_i}{n}, so BHi_{\text{i}} is true at k=k^ik=\hat{k}_i, which means there are k^i\hat{k}_i values that are ‚â§Œ±k^in\leq \alpha \frac{\hat{k}_i}{n}, so BH is true at k=k^ik=\hat{k}_i, and thus k^‚â•k^i\hat{k}\geq \hat{k}_i. It follows that k^=k^i\hat{k}=\hat{k}_i

With this claim, we can move onto the main result. We have FDR=ùîº[FDP]=ùîº[‚àëi null1{pi is rejected}max(1,k^)]=‚àëi nullùîº[1{pi is rejectedmax(1,k^)].\text{FDR}=\mathbb{E}[\text{FDP}]=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\sum_{i\text{ null}} \mathbf{1}\{p_i\text{ is rejected}\}}{\max(1, \hat{k})}\right]=\sum_{i\text{ null}} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\text{ is rejected}}{\max(1,\hat{k})}\right]. We can replace the denominator with k^i\hat{k}_i without changing the sum, because when they differ, the numerator is 0, so it doesn‚Äôt matter. Then, this is ‚àëi nullùîº[1{pi rejected}k^i]‚â§‚àëi nullùîº[1{pi‚â§Œ±k^in}k^i].\sum_{i\text{ null}}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\text{ rejected}\}}{\hat{k}_i}\right]\leq \sum_{i\text{ null}}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\leq \alpha \frac{\hat{k}_i}{n}\}}{\hat{k}_i}\right]. This is an inequality because if the first numerator is 1, the second is definitely 1, but if the first is 0, the second might not be.

Now, we use the tower law to write this as ‚àëi nullùîº[ùîº[1{pi‚â§Œ±‚ãÖk^i/n}ki|pj,j‚â†i]].\sum_{i\text{ null}} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\leq \alpha\cdot \hat{k}_i/n\}}{k_i}\Big| p_j, j\neq i\right]\right]. That conditional expectation is just ‚Ñô{pi‚â§Œ±k^i/n‚à£pj,j‚â†i}k^i=Œ±k^i/nk^i=Œ±/n.\frac{\mathbb{P}\{p_i\leq \alpha\hat{k}_i/n\mid p_j, j\neq i\}}{\hat{k}_i}=\frac{\alpha \hat{k}_i/n}{\hat{k}_i}=\alpha/n. This is a constant, and the expected value of that is just Œ±/n\alpha/n. When you add this over all the null terms, you get Œ±n0n\alpha\frac{n_0}{n}, as desired. ‚óº\blacksquare

Here, we actually get a better bound than Œ±\alpha, which might seem like a good thing, but also means we‚Äôre not making as many discoveries as we could be. We can correct for this by estimating n0n_0, and then running BH with Œ±nn0\alpha\frac{n}{n_0}, so that the FDR for this procedure will be ‚â§Œ±\leq \alpha.

Although we used independence here, we can make do without it, albeit at the cost of a logarithmic factor.

Proposition 5. When running Benjamini-Hochberg, we have FDR‚â§Œ±n0nHn\text{FDR}\leq \alpha\frac{n_0}{n}H_n.

Proof. As before, we define a score sis_i for each pip_i that is 1 if 0‚â§pi‚â§Œ±1n0\leq p_i\leq \alpha \frac{1}{n}, 12\frac{1}{2} if Œ±1n<pi‚â§Œ±2n,\alpha\frac{1}{n}<p_i\leq \alpha \frac{2}{n}, and so on, giving a score of 0 if pi>Œ±p_i>\alpha.

We proved above that for a null pp-value, the expected score is Œ±n(1+‚ãØ+1n).\frac{\alpha}{n}\left(1+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}\right). Now, we write FDR=‚àëi nullùîº[1{pi rejected}max(1,k^)].\text{FDR}=\sum_{i\text{ null}} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\text{ rejected}\}}{\max(1, \hat{k})}\right]. If pip_i is rejected, then pi‚â§Œ±k^/np_i\leq \alpha \hat{k}/n, so its score is ‚â•1/k^\geq 1/\hat{k}. Put another way, 1{pi rejected}max(1,k^)‚â§si.\frac{\mathbf{1}\{p_i\text{ rejected}\}}{\max(1, \hat{k})}\leq s_i.

Thus, FDR‚â§‚àëi nullùîº[si]=Œ±n0n(1+‚ãØ+1n).‚óº\text{FDR}\leq \sum_{i\text{ null}} \mathbb{E}[s_i]=\alpha\frac{n_0}{n}\left(1+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}\right). \blacksquare

entry.title: Percolation I: Critical Probabilities
entry.content:
This is the first in a series of posts about percolation theory, which I‚Äôm studying this summer. The main text I‚Äôm using is this one, and I plan to follow it pretty closely. There should be around six posts, culminating in the proof of the Harris-Kesten theorem, a major result about percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2. This material corresponds to the first three chapters of Bollobas, with some omissions and rearrangement.

1. The Big Picture

The idea is to consider some graph (prototypically ‚Ñ§d\mathbb{Z}^d but theoretically any graph), and choose a random subgraph of this graph by selecting each edge to be part of the subgraph with probability pp. Alternatively, do the same thing with vertices instead of edges, and take the subgraph to be the one induced by the chosen vertices.

Some terminology:

  • The edges are bonds
  • The vertices are sites
  • The chosen edges/vertices are open
  • The chosen graph is the open subgraph
  • The connected components of the open subgraph are open clusters

According to this language, the two models described above are bond percolation and site percolation.

The physical motivation for this model is a liquid percolating through a solid lattice, where the open bonds/sites represent the bonds/sites that the liquid can pass through. The main question suggested by this interpretation is whether the liquid will be able to pass through the lattice completely, which corresponds to the existence of an infinite open cluster.

The Harris-Kesten theorem mentioned above answers this question for bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2. It shows that for p>12p>\frac{1}{2}, there is an infinite open cluster with probability 1, and for p<12p<\frac{1}{2} there is an infinite open cluster with probability 0.

This post takes the first step toward proving this result by defining two critical probabilities that are closely related to this question, and then computing them for some simple graphs. Before we can even take that step though, we must construct a probability space (Œ£,‚Ñô)(\Sigma, \mathbb{P}) in which to work. For a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E), we take:

  1. Œ©={0,1}|E|\Omega=\{0,1\}^{|E|} to be the set of all arrangements of open edges, where 0 represents a closed edge and 1 represents an open edge;
  2. Œ£\Sigma to be the œÉ\sigma-algebra on Œ©\Omega generated by the cylinders C(F,œÉ)={œâ‚ààŒ©‚à£œâf=œÉf for f‚ààF},F‚äÇE and œÉ={0,1}|F|;C(F, \sigma)=\{\omega \in \Omega\mid \omega_f = \sigma_f\text{ for } f\in F\},\quad F\subset E\text{ and }\sigma =\{0,1\}^{|F|};
  3. ‚Ñô\mathbb{P} to be the probability measure on Œ£\Sigma induced by ‚Ñô(C(F,œÉ))=(‚àèf‚ààFœÉf=1p)(‚àèf‚ààFœÉf=01‚àíp).\mathbb{P}(C(F, \sigma))=\left(\prod_{\substack{f\in F\\ \sigma_f=1}} p\right)\left(\prod_{\substack{f\in F\\ \sigma_f=0}} 1-p\right).

In everything that follows, all probabilities are defined according to this measure.

2. Critical Probabilities

For a site xx, let CxC_x be the open cluster containing xx, and let Œ∏x(p)\theta_x(p) be the probability that CxC_x is infinite.

Proposition 1. There is a critical probability pHp_H such that Œ∏x(p)=0\theta_x(p)=0 if p<pHp<p_H and Œ∏x(p)>0\theta_x(p)>0 if p<pHp<p_H, for all xx.

(The notation pHp_H is in honor of Hammersley, who first proposed this model.)

Proof. Take any two sites x,yx, y such that |x‚àíy|=d|x-y|=d (this is the distance induced by GG). Then Œ∏x(p)‚â•pdŒ∏y(p)\theta_x(p)\geq p^d \theta_y(p), since if there is an infinite open cluster containing yy and a path from yy to xx, there will be an infinite open cluster containing xx as well. Thus, if Œ∏x(p)=0\theta_x(p)=0 for one site, then Œ∏x(p)=0\theta_x(p)=0 for all sites, and if Œ∏x(p)>0\theta_x(p)>0 for one site, then Œ∏x(p)>0\theta_x(p)>0 for all sites. If we show that Œ∏x(p)\theta_x(p) is an increasing function of pp, the existence of pHp_H follows.

To see the increasing behavior (which is intuitively clear), consider assigning each edge ee an independent random variable Xe‚àºUni[0,1]X_e\sim \text{Uni}[0,1], and then taking it to be open if Xe<pX_e<p. If p1<p2p_1<p_2, the subgraph obtained with probability p1p_1 will always be contained in the subgraph obtained with probability p2p_2, so Œ∏x(p)\theta_x(p) must be increasing.‚óº\blacksquare

We now connect this pHp_H to our original question about the existence of an infinite open cluster.

Corollary 2. Let EE be the event that there is an infinite open cluster. Then ‚Ñô(E)=1\mathbb{P}(E)=1 if p>pHp>p_H and ‚Ñô(E)=0\mathbb{P}(E)=0 if p<pHp<p_H.

Proof. The event EE is a tail event, so by the Kolmogorov 0-1 law, it can only take the values 0 and 1. If p<pHp<p_H, then ‚Ñô(E)‚â§‚àësites xŒ∏x(p)=0,\mathbb{P}(E)\leq \sum_{\text{sites }x} \theta_x(p)=0, so ‚Ñô(E)=0\mathbb{P}(E)=0. If p>pHp>p_H, then ‚Ñô(E)‚â•Œ∏x(p)>0\mathbb{P}(E)\geq \theta_x(p)>0 for at least one site, so ‚Ñô(E)=1\mathbb{P}(E)=1.‚óº\blacksquare

So to understand when there is an infinite open cluster, it suffices to understand pHp_H.

When p<pHp<p_H, any CxC_x is almost surely finite, but it‚Äôs expected size might not be. Set $\chi_x(p)=\E(|C_x|)$. By the same arguments as before, œáx(p)\chi_x(p) increases with pp, and it is either finite for all sites or for no sites. Thus we define pT=sup{p‚à£œáx(p)<‚àû},p_T=\sup\{p\mid \chi_x(p)<\infty\}, with the notation in honor of Temperley this time.

We have been deliberately ambiguous until now about whether we are working with bond percolation or site percolation in this section, and in fact we mean both. That is, there are actually four critical probabilities: pTb,pTs,pHb,pHsp_T^{\text{b}}, p_T^{\text{s}}, p_H^{\text{b}}, p_H^{\text{s}}. And since each of these depends on the choice of graph, we actually need to write pTs(G)p_T^{\text{s}}(G). This notation is a bit cumbersome though, so we refrain from using it except where absolutely necessary.

One obvious relationship between pTp_T and pHp_H is that pT‚â§pHp_T\leq p_H. Some more difficult relations are known, but we‚Äôll look at those in a later post. For now, let‚Äôs do an example.

3. Computing the Critical Probabilities

Determining pTp_T and pHp_H in general is quite hard (after all, the Harris-Kesten theorem basically boils down to doing this for ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2, and is already highly non-trivial), but there are some simple graphs for which it can be done. We do an example with bond percolation.

Suppose G=TkG=T_k is the tree in which every vertex has degree k+1k+1, except for the root which has degree kk. Consider the function f(x)=1‚àí(1‚àípx)kf(x)=1-(1-px)^k. The œÄn\pi_n result from iterating this function starting with œÄ0=1\pi_0=1, so we need to study it‚Äôs fixed points. We have f(0)=0f(0)=0 and f(1)<1f(1)<1. If f‚Ä≤(0)>1f'(0)>1, then f(œµ)>œµf(\epsilon)>\epsilon for some small œµ>0\epsilon>0, but f(1)<1f(1)<1, so there is some fixed point x0x_0. Otherwise, the unique fixed point is at x=0x=0. Concretely, f‚Ä≤(0)=pkf'(0)=pk, so this condition reduces to p>1kp>\frac{1}{k}.

In the case where p>1kp>\frac{1}{k}, we see that œÄn‚àí1‚â•x0‚üπœÄn‚â•x0\pi_{n-1}\geq x_0\implies \pi_n\geq x_0, and since œÄ0=1‚â•x0\pi_0=1\geq x_0, we always have œÄn‚â•x0\pi_n\geq x_0. On the other hand, if p‚â§1kp\leq \frac{1}{k}, the œÄn\pi_n converge to the unique fixed point at 0, meaning that Œ∏v0(p)=0\theta_{v_0}(p)=0. It follows that pH=1kp_H=\frac{1}{k} for TkT_k.

We can also do pTp_T: a site at depth ‚Ñì\ell is part of Cv0C_{v_0} with probability p‚Ñìp^{\ell}, so œáv0(p)=‚àëy‚ààTk‚Ñô(y‚ààCv0)=‚àë‚Ñì=0‚àûk‚Ñìp‚Ñì,\chi_{v_0}(p)=\sum_{y\in T_k} \mathbb{P}(y\in C_{v_0})=\sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} k^{\ell}p^{\ell}, which is finite if and only if pk<1pk<1. A few remarks about this calculation: the fact that pT=pHp_T=p_H here is not unusual. This is true for a very general class of graphs.

Also, it turns out that this tree TkT_k has, in some sense, the lowest critical probability possible. To see this, take GG to be a graph with maximum degree Œî\Delta. If y‚ààCxy\in C_x, then there is an open path from yy to xx, so we can bound œáx(p)\chi_x(p) by the number of paths in GG that start at xx. Using our information about the maximum degree, this gives œáx(p)‚â§1+‚àë‚Ñì=1‚àûŒî(Œî‚àí1)‚Ñì‚àí1p‚Ñì,\chi_x(p)\leq 1+\sum_{\ell=1}^{\infty} \Delta(\Delta-1)^{\ell-1} p^{\ell}, which converges exactly when p<1Œî‚àí1p<\frac{1}{\Delta-1}. This means that pT‚â•1Œî‚àí1p_T\geq \frac{1}{\Delta-1}, and since pH‚â•pTp_H\geq p_T, this bound holds for pHp_H as well. In TkT_k, Œî=k+1\Delta=k+1, and this bound is attained.

So the tree TkT_k is special in more ways than one. It turns out that the more ‚Äútree-like‚Äù a graph is, the more easily pTp_T and pHp_H can be computed. Unfortunately, ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 is nothing like a tree, so a different approach is required to tackle it.

entry.content:
This post presents a couple of results regarding percolation on ‚Ñ§d\mathbb{Z}^d (and especially ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2), which are valuable mainly because they tell us that percolation on these graphs is non-trivial i.e.¬†none of the critical probabilities is 0 or 1. But on a concrete level, they actually do more: they give explicit bounds on the critical probabilities.

Proposition 1. For bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2, we have pT‚â•13p_T\geq \frac{1}{3}

This proof hinges on counting Œºn(‚Ñ§2)\mu_n(\mathbb{Z}^2), the number of self-avoiding walks of length nn (in the language of graph theory, paths) on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2. We will make use of the obvious bound Œºn(‚Ñ§2)‚â§4‚ãÖ3n‚àí1.\mu_n(\mathbb{Z}^2)\leq 4\cdot 3^{n-1}.

Proof. The middle inequality was discussed in the previous post, so it suffices to do the first and last ones. Let‚Äôs start with the first.

Choose some p<13p<\frac{1}{3} and consider the bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 where every bond is open with probability pp. Let C0C_0 be the cluster containing the origin and note that any site in C0C_0 must be connected to the origin by an open path starting at the origin. (It‚Äôs a little hard to see, but this is where the self-avoiding condition comes in: if the walk from the origin to the site intersected itself, we could ‚Äúexcise‚Äù the loop and then get another path that‚Äôs more likely to be open, because it is shorter.) The size of C0C_0 is bounded by the number XX of such paths and the probaibility of a path of length nn being open is pnp^n, so ùîº(|C0|)‚â§ùîº(X)=‚àën=0‚àûpnŒºn‚â§1+‚àën=1‚àûpn‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ3n‚àí1<‚àû,\mathbb{E}(|C_0|)\leq \mathbb{E}(X)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} p^n\mu_n\leq 1+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} p^n\cdot 4\cdot 3^{n-1}<\infty, because p<13p<\frac{1}{3}. Since the expected size of C0C_0 is finite for any p<13p<\frac{1}{3}, we conclude that pT‚â•13p_T\geq \frac{1}{3}. ‚óº\blacksquare

Proposition 2. For bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2, we have pH‚â§23p_H\leq \frac{2}{3}

This proof hinges on studying the dual graph of ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 (more on this in a second) and using a technical lemma that I won‚Äôt prove.

For a graph Œõ\Lambda, the dual Œõ*\Lambda^* is a graph whose vertices correspond to faces of Œõ\Lambda with edges connecting adjacent faces in Œõ\Lambda. For example, (‚Ñ§2)*=‚Ñ§2+(0.5,0.5).\left(\mathbb{Z}^2\right)^*=\mathbb{Z}^2+(0.5,0.5).

In the context of percolation, we call the sites and bonds of Œõ*\Lambda^* dual sites and dual bonds, with a dual bond taken to be closed when the original bond is open, or vice versa. (We‚Äôre associating bonds to dual bonds here by e‚Ü¶e*e\mapsto e^* where e*e^* is the edge of Œõ*\Lambda^* connecting the faces of Œõ\Lambda that meet at ee).

In ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2, if HH is a finite subgraph of ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 with vertex set CC, then ‚Ñ§2\C\mathbb{Z}^2\setminus C must have some infinite component C‚àûC_{\infty}. We define ‚àÇ‚àûC\partial^{\infty} C to be the bonds of (‚Ñ§2)*\left(\mathbb{Z}^2\right)^* that are dual to bonds of ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 joining CC and C‚àûC_{\infty}.

Put another way, you take some finite subgraph, and look at all the edges connecting it to the infinite component of it‚Äôs complement. This set of edges maps to some set of edges in the dual, and that set is ‚àÇ‚àûC\partial^{\infty} C. The lemma says that ‚àÇ‚àûC\partial^{\infty} C looks like the boundary of HH.

Lemma 3. ‚àÇ‚àûC\partial^{\infty} C is a cycle containing CC.

Proof of Proposition 2. As before, take some p>23p>\frac{2}{3}, and consider bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 where each bond is open with probability pp. Take dual bonds e*e^* to be open if ee is closed and vice versa, and call a cycle in the dual consisting of open bonds an open dual cycle.

Let LkL_k be the segment connecting the origin to (k,0)(k,0) and SS some dual cycle of length 2‚Ñì2\ell surrounding LkL_k. SS must cut the xx-axis between k+0.5k+0.5 and 0.5(2‚Ñì‚àí3)0.5(2\ell-3), so there are fewer than ‚Ñì\ell choices for the dual bond that cuts the xx-axis. The rest of SS is a path of length 2‚Ñì‚àí12\ell-1, and since the dual of ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 is isomorphic to ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2, there are Œº2‚Ñì‚àí1\mu_{2\ell-1} possibilities for this portion of SS. In total, we have fewer than ‚ÑìŒº2‚Ñì‚àí1\ell \mu_{2\ell-1} possibilities for SS.

Let YkY_k be the number of open dual cycles surrounding LkL_k. An open dual cycle of length 2‚Ñì2\ell occurs with probability (1‚àíp)2‚Ñì(1-p)^{2\ell}, so ùîº(Yk)‚â§‚àë‚Ñì=k+2‚àû‚ÑìŒº2‚Ñì‚àí1(1‚àíp)2‚Ñì‚â§‚àë‚Ñì=k+2‚àû‚Ñì‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ32‚Ñì‚àí2(1‚àíp)2‚Ñì<‚àû,\mathbb{E}(Y_k)\leq \sum_{\ell=k+2}^{\infty} \ell\mu_{2\ell-1}(1-p)^{2\ell}\leq \sum_{\ell =k+2}^{\infty} \ell\cdot 4\cdot 3^{2\ell-2}(1-p)^{2\ell}<\infty, because p>23‚üπ3(1‚àíp)<1p>\frac{2}{3}\implies 3(1-p)<1.

This means that ùîº(Yk)‚Üí0\mathbb{E}(Y_k)\to 0 as k‚Üí‚àûk\to \infty, and in particular, ùîº(Yk)<1\mathbb{E}(Y_k)<1 eventually. If AkA_k is the event that Yk=0Y_k=0, this means that ‚Ñô(Ak)>0\mathbb{P}(A_k)>0 (if P(Ak)P(A_k) were never zero, then integrating over a set of measure 1 would have to give something that is at least 1). Now let BkB_k be the event that all the bonds in LkL_k are open, which occurs with probability pkp^k, which is independent of AkA_k.

If AkA_k and BkB_k both occur, then C0C_0 cannot be contained in a cycle of the dual graph (since Yk=0Y_k=0), so it must be infinite by our lemma. Thus Œ∏0(p)=‚Ñô(|C0|=‚àû)‚â•‚Ñô(Ak‚à©Bk)=‚Ñô(Ak)‚Ñô(Bk)‚â•‚Ñô(Ak)pk>0,\theta_0(p)=\mathbb{P}(|C_0|=\infty)\geq \mathbb{P}(A_k\cap B_k)= \mathbb{P}(A_k)\mathbb{P}(B_k)\geq \mathbb{P}(A_k)p^k>0, so there is an infinite open cluster with probability 1. This means that pH‚â•pp_H\geq p, and since pp is any probability >23>\frac{2}{3}, we have pH‚â§23p_H\leq \frac{2}{3}. ‚óº\blacksquare

Remark 1.

  1. Recalling that pT‚â§pHp_T\leq p_H, we can chain these together into 13‚â§pT‚â§pH‚â§23,\frac{1}{3}\leq p_T\leq p_H\leq \frac{2}{3}, showing that the critical probabilities for bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 are non-trivial.
  2. The bound of Œºn‚â§4‚ãÖ3n‚àí1\mu_n\leq 4\cdot 3^{n-1} is crude, and these inequalities can be sharpened by using tighter inequalities. For example, noting that Œºm+n‚â§ŒºmŒºn\mu_{m+n}\leq \mu_m\mu_n (you can just concatenate paths), we see by Fekete‚Äôs lemma that Œºn1/n‚ÜíŒª\mu_n^{1/n}\to \lambda. This Œª\lambda is called the connective constant, and our result becomes 1Œª‚â§pT‚â§pH‚â§1‚àí1Œª,\frac{1}{\lambda}\leq p_T\leq p_H\leq 1-\frac{1}{\lambda}, so we just need to estimate this constant, which I won‚Äôt get into but can certainly be done.
  3. Since ‚Ñ§d\mathbb{Z}^d contains ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z}^2 within it for d‚â•2d\geq 2, we can recall the result at the end of the previous post to obtain 12d‚àí1‚â§pT(‚Ñ§d)‚â§pH(‚Ñ§d)‚â§23,\frac{1}{2d-1}\leq p_T(\mathbb{Z}^d)\leq p_H(\mathbb{Z}^d)\leq \frac{2}{3}, giving non-triviality of critical probabilities for ‚Ñ§d\mathbb{Z}^d.

These results are only for bond percolation. We can use them to say things about site percolation as well though, by showing that percolation is ‚Äúmore likely‚Äù in the site model than the bond model.

Theorem 4. For any graph Œõ\Lambda, we have pHs‚â•pHbp_H^{\mathrm{s}}\geq p_H^{\mathrm{b}} and pTs‚â•pTbp_T^{\mathrm{s}}\geq p_T^{\mathrm{b}}.

Proof. The key claim is that for any site xx, integer nn, and probability pp, ‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n)‚â§p‚Ñôb(|Cx|‚â•n).\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n)\leq p \mathbb{P}^{\text{b}}(|C_x|\geq n). (Here, ‚Ñôb\mathbb{P}^{\text{b}} and ‚Ñôs\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}} are the probability measures induced by bond and site percolation where bonds and sites are open with probability pp, respectively. Throughout this proof, we use such superscripts to indicate the type of percolation being considered.)

From this claim, we let n‚Üí‚àûn\to \infty to obtain Œ∏xs‚â§pŒ∏xb\theta_x^{\text{s}}\leq p\theta_x^{\text{b}}. Then, if Œ∏xb=0\theta_x^{\text{b}}=0, we have Œ∏xs=0\theta_x^{\text{s}}=0 as well, so pHs‚â•pHbp_H^{\text{s}}\geq p_H^{\text{b}}.

For pTp_T, we argue similarly: œáxs=‚àën=1‚àû‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n)‚â§‚àën=1‚àû‚Ñôb(|Cx|‚â•n)‚â§pœáxb,\chi_x^{\text{s}}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n)\leq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mathbb{P}^{\text{b}}(|C_x|\geq n)\leq p\chi_x^{\text{b}}, and so œáxb<‚àû‚üπœáxs<‚àû\chi_x^{\text{b}}<\infty\implies \chi_x^{\text{s}}<\infty, meaning that pTs‚â•pTb.p_T^{\text{s}}\geq p_T^{\text{b}}.

It remains to show the claim. We begin by writing ‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n)\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n) as ‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n‚à£x is open)‚Ñôs(x is open)+‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n‚à£x is closed)‚Ñôs(x is closed).\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n\mid x\text{ is open})\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(x\text{ is open})+\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n\mid x\text{ is closed})\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(x\text{ is closed}). Thus we see that ‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n)=p‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n‚à£x is open),\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n)=p\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n\mid x\text{ is open}), and so our claim is equivalent to p‚Ñôs(|Cx|‚â•n‚à£x is open)‚â•‚Ñôb(|Cx|‚â•n).p\mathbb{P}^{\text{s}}(|C_x|\geq n\mid x\text{ is open})\geq \mathbb{P}^{\text{b}}(|C_x|\geq n).

Next, we note that since the event |Cxs|‚â•n|C_x^{\text{s}}|\geq n depends only on vertices that are within nn of xx, it suffices to consider the subgraph Œõn\Lambda_n of points within nn of xx. The idea now is to construct a sequence of subsets of V(Œõn)V(\Lambda_n) (the vertex set of Œõn)\Lambda_n) denoted ùíØ=(Rt,Dt,Ut)t=1‚Ñì\mathcal{T}=(R_t, D_t, U_t)_{t=1}^{\ell} such that R‚Ñì=CxsR_{\ell}= C_x^{\text{s}}.   2. Pick a bond et=ytzte_t=y_tz_t where yt‚ààRty_t\in R_t and zt‚ààUtz_t\in U_t. Remove ztz_t from UtU_t. If yty_t is open, add it to RtR_t and leave DtD_t alone; otherwise add it to DtD_t and leave RtR_t alone. This gives the new triplet.

So this shows that pHs,pTsp_H^{\text{s}}, p_T^{\text{s}} are not zero. To show that they are also not 1, we need another inequality, namely:

Theorem 5. For percolation on an infinite connected graph with maximum degree Œî\Delta, pHs‚â§1‚àí(1‚àípHb)Œî‚àí1.p_H^{\mathrm{s}}\leq 1-(1-p_H^{\mathrm{b}})^{\Delta-1}.

entry.content:
The next chapter of Bollobas is a collection of probabilistic tools used throughout the book; this post presents two of these results that will be key to our proof of the Harris-Kesten theorem. Both of these results are set in the framework of weighted hypercubes, which we now introduce.

Take a set SS and its power set ùí´(S)\mathcal{P}(S). This power set can be identified with the set of functions f:S‚Üí{0,1}f: S\to \{0,1\} by identifying A‚ààùí´(S)A\in \mathcal{P}(S) with its characteristic function. In the case where SS is finite (and this is the case we care about), we can think of SS as {1,‚ãØ,n}\{1,\cdots, n\} and ùí´(S)=ùí´(n)\mathcal{P}(S)=\mathcal{P}(n) as the cube Qn={0,1}n.Q^n=\{0,1\}^n. This cube is the set of binary sequences of length nn, where a subset A‚äÇSA\subset S is associated to a sequence that has a 1 in position ii if i‚ààAi\in A and a 0 otherwise.

More geometrically, we can think of QnQ^n as a graph whose vertices are ùí´(n)\mathcal{P}(n). Two sets A,BA, B are connected in this graph if |AŒîB|=1|A\Delta B|=1 (i.e. AA and BB differ at one entry in their sequences). Put yet another way, if ùêö,ùêõ‚àà{0,1}n\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\in \{0,1\}^n are two vertices, they are connected if a‚àíb=¬±ùêûia-b=\pm \mathbf{e}_i, where ùêûi\mathbf{e}_i is a standard basis vector. We can make QnQ^n a directed graph by saying the edge ùêöùêõ\mathbf{a}\mathbf{b} is oriented from ùêö\mathbf{a} to ùêõ\mathbf{b} if ùêõ‚àíùêö=ùêûi\mathbf{b}-\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{e}_i. We write this as ùêö‚â§ùêõ\mathbf{a}\leq \mathbf{b}.

Now, shifting gears, the points of QnQ^n are associated with the outcome of a sequence of nn coin tosses. If ùê©=(p1,‚ãØ,pn)\mathbf{p}=(p_1,\cdots, p_n) is the sequence of probabilities of success for these nn coin tosses, then $ $ induces a natural probability measure on QnQ^n.

For example, if ùê©=(0.5,‚ãØ,0.5)\mathbf{p}=(0.5,\cdots, 0.5) we obtain the uniform measure, and if ùê©=(p,‚ãØ,p)\mathbf{p}=(p,\cdots, p), we obtain ‚Ñô(A)=p|A|(1‚àíp)n‚àí|A|\mathbb{P} (A)=p^{|A|}(1-p)^{n-|A|}. We write QpnQ_p^n for the cube with this measure, and it is equivalent to the standard percolation models.

We write Qùê©nQ_{\mathbf{p}}^n for the probability space (‚Ñôùê©,Qn)(\mathbb{P} _{\mathbf{p}}, Q^n) and distinguish two kinds of events. A subset U‚äÇQnU\subset Q^n is an up-set if a,b‚ààQn,a‚â§b‚üπb‚ààUa,b\in Q^n, a\leq b\implies b\in U. Similarly, UU is a down-set if a,b‚ààQn,a‚â•b‚üπb‚ààUa,b \in Q^n, a\geq b\implies b\in U. (Keep in mind that UU is a subset of QnQ^n, which is identified with ùí´(S)\mathcal{P}(S), so a,ba, b are subsets of the original set SS.) With that set up out of the way, we can state our first lemma.

1. Harris‚Äôs Lemma

This lemma is the intuitive fact that increasing events are positively correlated. Let‚Äôs do a bit more set up.

For a set A‚äÇQnA\subset Q^n and t=0,1t=0,1 we can define At={(ai)i=1n‚àí1‚à£(a1,‚ãØ,an‚àí1,t)‚ààA}‚äÇQn‚àí1.A_t=\{(a_i)_{i=1}^{n-1}\mid (a_1,\cdots, a_{n-1}, t)\in A\}\subset Q^{n-1}. If AA is an up-set, A0‚äÇA1A_0\subset A_1, and if AA is a down-set, A1‚äÇA0A_1\subset A_0 (because A1,A0A_1, A_0 always differ at only one position, so their difference is always a basis vector, so it‚Äôs just a matter of sign).

From this first piece, the other inequality follows easily: if AA is an up-set and BB is a down-set, then BcB^c is an up-set, so ‚Ñô(A‚à©B)‚â§‚Ñô(A)‚àí‚Ñô(A‚à©Bc)‚â§‚Ñô(A)‚àí‚Ñô(A)‚Ñô(Bc),\mathbb{P} (A\cap B)\leq\mathbb{P} (A)-\mathbb{P} (A\cap B^c)\leq \mathbb{P} (A)-\mathbb{P} (A)\mathbb{P} (B^c), from the previous result. This then is ‚Ñô(A)‚àí‚Ñô(A)(1‚àí‚Ñô(B))=‚Ñô(A)‚Ñô(B),\mathbb{P} (A)-\mathbb{P} (A)(1-\mathbb{P} (B))=\mathbb{P} (A)\mathbb{P} (B), as desired. ‚óº\blacksquare

entry.title: Percolation IV: Harris‚Äôs Theorem
entry.content:
We‚Äôre ready to start proving the Harris-Kesten theorem, so from now on, everything we say is about bond percolation in ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z} ^2. The global structure of the argument is in three steps:

  1. Show that Œ∏(1/2)=0\theta(1/2)=0 (this implies pH‚â•1/2p_H\geq 1/2)
  2. Show that for p>1/2p>1/2, there is an infinite open cluster with probability 1 (this implies pH‚â§1/2p_H\leq 1/2)
  3. Show that œá(p)<‚àû\chi(p)<\infty for p<1/2p<1/2 (this implies that pT‚â•1/2p_T\geq 1/2)
  4. Conclude that pT=pH=1/2p_T=p_H=1/2

This post will accomplish the first step.

1. Crossing Probabilities

We start with some more definitions: a rectangle RR in ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z} ^2 is a set of sites of the form [a,b]√ó[c,d][a,b]\times [c,d]. We say this rectangle has size k√ó‚Ñìk\times \ell, where k=b‚àía+1,‚Ñì=d‚àíc+1k=b-a+1, \ell=d-c+1. It contains k‚Ñìk\ell sites and 2k‚Ñì‚àík‚àí‚Ñì2k\ell-k-\ell bonds.

This rectangle has two duals: a horizontal dual Rh=[a+0.5,b‚àí0.5]√ó[c‚àí0.5,d+0.5]R^h=[a+0.5, b-0.5]\times [c-0.5, d+0.5] and a vertical dual Rv=[a‚àí0.5,b+0.5]√ó[c+0.5,d‚àí0.5].R^v=[a-0.5, b+0.5]\times [c+0.5, d-0.5]. We have that RhR^h is a k‚àí1√ó‚Ñì+1k-1\times \ell+1 rectangle and RvR^v is a k+1√ó‚Ñì‚àí1k+1\times \ell-1 rectangle. Additionally, (Rh)v=(Rv)h=R.\left(R^h\right)^v=\left(R^v\right)^h=R.

Finally, we define an open horizontal crossing of a rectangle RR to be an open path in RR connecting a site (a,x)(a,x) to a site (b,y)(b,y), and similarly for an open vertical crossing. We write H(R)H(R) and V(R)V(R) for the events that such crossings exist.

The following lemma is, according to Bollobas, the ‚Äúreason‚Äù why pH=1/2p_H=1/2. It is intuitively clear, but working through all the details is a bit of slog, so let‚Äôs just take it at face value.

Lemma 1. Let RR be a rectangle in ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z} ^2 or its dual. Then exactly one of H(R)H(R) and V(Rh)V(R^h) holds.

Why exactly is this lemma the ‚Äúreason‚Äù cited above? The following corollary sheds some light on that.

Corollary 2. If RR and R‚Ä≤R' are k√ó‚Ñì‚àí1k\times \ell-1 and k‚àí1√ó‚Ñìk-1\times \ell rectangles in ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z} ^2, then ‚Ñôp(H(R))+‚Ñô1‚àíp(V(R‚Ä≤))=1.\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))+\mathbb{P} _{1-p}(V(R'))=1.

Proof. The bonds of the dual are open when the bonds of the original graph are closed and vice versa. So by Lemma 1, each configuration of bonds will satisfy exactly one of H(R)H(R) and V(Rh)V(R^h), so ‚Ñô(H(R))+‚Ñô(V(Rh))=1.\mathbb{P} (H(R))+\mathbb{P} (V(R^h))=1. But RhR^h is indistinguishable from R‚Ä≤R', so the result follows. ‚óº\blacksquare

Now if we take k=‚Ñìk=\ell in this corollary, we get that for an n+1√ónn+1\times n rectangle RR, ‚Ñô1/2(H(R))+‚Ñô1/2(V(R‚Ä≤))=1.\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(R))+\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(V(R'))=1. But because the rectangle R‚Ä≤R' has dimension n√ón+1n\times n+1, the event V(R‚Ä≤)V(R') has the same probability as H(R‚Ä≤)H(R'), so they are both equal to 1/21/2.

So the intuition is somehow that when p>1/2p>1/2, it‚Äôs more likely you have a horizontal crossing than not, so you get an infinite open cluster. When p<1/2p<1/2, it‚Äôs less likely than not, so you don‚Äôt. The critical behavior is at exactly p=1/2p=1/2.

More importantly, we get that if SS is an n√ónn\times n square, ‚Ñô1/2(V(S))=‚Ñô1/2(H(S))‚â•12,\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(V(S))=\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(S))\geq \frac{1}{2}, where we have the inequality because this event must be more likely than the crossing for an n√ón+1n\times n+1 rectangle. This is a bound on the crossing probabilities of a square. We now have to extend this result to rectangles.

2. Squares to Rectangles

This next lemma relates crossings of squares to crossings of rectangles. We use the notation [n]=[0,n][n]=[0,n].

Lemma 3. Consider R=[m]√ó[2n]R=[m]\times [2n], an m√ó2nm\times 2n rectangle with m‚â•nm\geq n. Let X(R)X(R) be the event that there are open paths P1,P2P_1, P_2 such that P1P_1 crosses the n√ónn\times n square S=[n]√ó[n]S=[n]\times [n] from top to bottom and P2P_2 lies within RR and joins some site on P1P_1 to the right hand side of RR. Then ‚Ñôp(X(R))‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))‚Ñôp(V(S))2.\mathbb{P} _p(X(R))\geq \frac{\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))\mathbb{P} _p(V(S))}{2}.

Proof. Suppose V(S)V(S) occurs, so an open path P0P_0 crosses SS from top to bottom. Such a path cuts SS into two pieces, one on the left and on the right. Let LV(S)LV(S) be the left-most open vertical crossing (when one exists). For any P1P_1, the event {LV(S)=P1}\{LV(S)=P_1\} does not depend on bonds to the right of P1P_1.

The key claim is that ‚Ñôp(X(R)‚à£LV(S)=P1)‚â•‚Ñô(H(R))2.\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)\mid LV(S)=P_1)\geq \frac{\mathbb{P} (H(R))}{2}. Since V(S)V(S) is a disjoint union of events of the form {LV(S)=P1}\{LV(S)=P_1\}, this implies that ‚Ñôp(X(R)‚à£V(S))‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))2,\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)\mid V(S))\geq\frac{\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))}{2}, which rearranges to ‚Ñôp(X(R)‚à©V(S))‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))‚Ñôp(V(S))2.\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)\cap V(S))\geq \frac{\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))\mathbb{P} _p(V(S))}{2}. But X(R)X(R) occurring means that V(S)V(S) does as well, so ‚Ñôp(X(R)‚à©V(S))=‚Ñôp(X(R))\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)\cap V(S))=\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)), and the lemma is proven.

For the claim, let PP be the path (that may or may not be open) formed by the union of P1P_1 and it‚Äôs reflection P1‚Ä≤P_1' in the horizontal axis of RR, with a bond joining P1P_1 to P1‚Ä≤P_1'. This path is a vertical crossing of the rectangle [n]√ó[2n][n]\times [2n].

Now, there is an open path P3P_3 crossing RR horizontally with probability ‚Ñôp(H(R))\mathbb{P} _p(H(R)). This path must meet PP, and the probability it does so at a site of P1P_1 is at least ‚Ñôp(H(R))/2\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))/2. Thus the event that there is an open path P2P_2 in RR to the right of PP joining a site of P1P_1 to the right end of RR has probability at least ‚Ñôp(H(R))/2\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))/2. This event depends only bonds to the right of PP, and all such bonds in SS are to the right of P1P_1. These bonds are independent of LV(S)=P1LV(S)=P_1, so ‚Ñôp(Y(P1)‚à£LV(S)=P1)=‚Ñôp(Y(P1))‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))/2.\mathbb{P} _p(Y(P_1)\mid LV(S)=P_1)=\mathbb{P} _p(Y(P_1))\geq \mathbb{P} _p(H(R))/2.

If Y(P1)Y(P_1) and LV(S)=P1LV(S)=P_1 both occur, then X(R)X(R) does as well. So ‚Ñôp(X(R)‚à£LV(S)=P1)‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))/2,\mathbb{P} _p(X(R)\mid LV(S)=P_1)\geq \mathbb{P} _p(H(R))/2, proving the claim and thus the lemma. ‚óº\blacksquare

Remark 1. If we instead take an m1√ó2nm_1\times 2n rectangle RR and an m2√ó2nm_2\times 2n rectangle R‚Ä≤R', this proof will show that h(m1+m2‚àín,2n)‚â•h(m1,2n)h(m2,2n)25,h(m_1+m_2-n, 2n)\geq \frac{h(m_1, 2n)h(m_2,2n)}{2^5}, and we will use this formulation later on.

(This argument is much simpler than it seems - drawing the picture goes a long way.)

3. Thinning the Rectangles Out

With this lemma, we can now bound the crossing probabilities for non-square rectangles. In particular, we look at a 3n√ó2n3n\times 2n rectangle. For convenience, let hp(m,n)=‚Ñôp(H(R))h_p(m,n)=\mathbb{P} _p(H(R)), and since it‚Äôs the case we really care about, h(m,n)=h1/2(m,n)h(m,n)=h_{1/2}(m,n).

Corollary 4. We have h(3n,2n)‚â•2‚àí7h(3n, 2n)\geq 2^{-7}.

Proof. Take two square 2n√ó2n2n\times 2n rectangles R,R‚Ä≤R, R' that overlap in an n√ó2nn\times 2n strip. This n√ó2nn\times 2n strip contains two n√ónn\times n squares; call SS the smaller of these. (Again, draw the picture!) Let X‚Ä≤(R‚Ä≤)X'(R') be the event X(R)X(R) described above, but reflected horizontally. Then we apply Lemma 4 to RR (which is coincidentally a square) to get ‚Ñôp(X‚Ä≤(R‚Ä≤))=‚Ñôp(X(R))‚â•‚Ñôp(H(R))‚Ñôp(V(S))2.\mathbb{P} _p(X'(R'))=\mathbb{P} _p(X(R))\geq \frac{\mathbb{P} _p(H(R))\mathbb{P} _p(V(S))}{2}.

Now, we call back to Harris‚Äôs lemma from the previous post: the events X(R),X‚Ä≤(R‚Ä≤),H(S)X(R), X'(R'), H(S) are all increasingly and positive correlated. If they all hold, so does H(R‚à™R‚Ä≤)H(R\cup R'), and so we have h(3n,2n)=‚Ñô1/2(H(R‚à™R‚Ä≤))‚â•‚Ñô1/2(X‚Ä≤(R‚Ä≤))‚Ñô1/2(X(R))‚Ñô1/2(H(S)).h(3n,2n)=\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(R\cup R'))\geq \mathbb{P} _{1/2}(X'(R'))\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(X(R))\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(S)). This is then ‚â•‚Ñô1/2(H(R))2‚Ñô1/2(V(S))2‚Ñô1/2(H(S))4.\geq \frac{\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(R))^2\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(V(S))^2\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(H(S))}{4}.

But by our observation at the end of Section 1, this is at least (0.52)34=2‚àí7,\frac{(0.5^2)^3}{4}=2^{-7}, as desired. blacksquareblacksquare

A 3n√ó2n3n\times 2n rectangle isn‚Äôt quite thing enough for our purposes, but the rest of the thinning can be done using the remark after Lemma 3. We have h(5n,2n)‚â•h(3m,2n)225‚â•2‚àí19,h(5n,2n)\geq \frac{h(3m,2n)^2}{2^5}\geq 2^{-19}, and so h(6n,2n)‚â•h(5n,2n)h(2n,2n)25‚â•2‚àí25,h(6n,2n)\geq \frac{h(5n,2n)h(2n,2n)}{2^5}\geq 2^{-25}, and this is the bound that our proof of Œ∏(1/2)=0\theta(1/2)=0 will hinge on.

4. Harris‚Äôs Theorem

Theorem 5 (Harris). For bond percolation on ‚Ñ§2\mathbb{Z} ^2, Œ∏(1/2)=0\theta(1/2)=0.

Proof. Let r(C0)=sup{d(x,0)‚à£x‚ààC0}.r(C_0)=\sup\{d(x,0)\mid x\in C_0\}. The actual result we‚Äôll show is that ‚Ñô1/2(r(C0)‚â•n)‚â§n‚àíc\mathbb{P} _{1/2}(r(C_0)\geq n)\leq n^{-c} for a constant cc, and the stated result follows from this.

When p=1/2p=1/2, bonds in the dual lattice are open with probability 1/21/2, so by the computation above, the probability a 6n√ó2n6n\times 2n rectangle has a crossing the long way is at least 2‚àí252^{-25}. Consider 4 such rectangles oriented to form an annulus around the origin, with the ‚Äúhole‚Äù in the annulus being a 2n√ó2n2n\times 2n square centered at the origin.

By Harris‚Äôs lemma, the probability each of these rectangles is crossed the long way by an open path in the dual is at least œµ=2‚àí100\epsilon=2^{-100}. The union of these paths is an open dual cycle around the annulus.

entry.title: LL Defense: A Cautionary Tale of Classification
entry.content:
‚ÄúYou mustn‚Äôt pay too much attention to [predictions]. The [outcome] is immutable, and the [predictions] are often only an expression of despair over it.‚Äù
‚Äì Franz Kafka

In June, a friend of mine introduced me to Learned League. The basic format is that you play a series of one-on-one trivia matches against a pool of opponents over the course of a season. At the end of the season, players are ranked, and moved to harder or easier pools for doing exceptionally well or poorly. Each individual match consists of six questions, which you have to try to answer correctly. But, crucially, the winner of a match is not the person who answers more questions correctly - it is the person who scores more points. The points are not pre-ordained; they are assigned by your opponent.

The point values for the six questions have to be assigned from the set {0,1,1,2,2,3}\{0, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3\}. If I think my opponent is very likely to get a question right, I would assign it 0 points. Conversely, a question I think my opponent is unlikely to get right would be assigned 3 points. This defensive assignment turns out to be quite important, almost as important as answering questions correctly. If you and your opponent answer the same number of questions correctly, which is not that unusual, the winner is determined by defense. If you and your opponent are within one question of each other, defense can still make a tie of a loss, or a win of a tie. This post outlines my attempts to improve my defense through algorithmic means, the code for which is available here.

1. Not Your Textbook‚Äôs Classification Task

How can I tell whether or not my opponent will get a question right? One way is to judge how difficult each question is, and go by that. The drawbacks of this are that it may be hard to judge difficulty for questions you know nothing about (e.g.¬†I have no way to tell if a sports question is easy or hard for someone who follows sports) and that even if you can judge, your opponent‚Äôs knowledge base might be different from yours. Luckily, the website shows you your opponents past accuracy broken down by category (for an example, see mine in the margin), and you can use this to inform things a bit.

Actually, you have access to a good bit more information than this: you can, if you want to, see all the questions your opponent has answered in the past, and whether or not they answered them correctly. This means, for example, that if your opponent has a history of answering of questions about islands correctly, you can discover as much and defend yourself accordingly. The drawback of this approach is that players can have extensive question histories that are inconvenient to trawl through, and it can also be hard to identify which questions are relevant to the current ones.

Enter machine learning. Predicting whether or not a new question will be answered correctly given a set of past questions is a textbook classification problem. So all you need to do is scrape the data you need, train the classifier, and watch your rankings climb.

Except not really. Complications:

  1. You have to train a new classifier for each opponent, and you only get as many training samples as they have question history. For opponents who have played only a single season, this is as few as 450, which might be enough to separate the classes, except
  2. Most of my opponents are about as good as I am, which is to say not every good. This makes the classes in the training data highly imbalanced - maybe as few as 45 of those 450 questions have been answered correctly. And even those might not be great samples, because
  3. The corpus of questions is full of oddball words that appear in only one question. Some of these are foreign words, others are just highly specific, but either way, a given question may be useless for informing decisions about any others.

These complications are hardly insurmountable though, so I gave it a shot.

2. Into the (Random) Forest

Random forests seemed like a good choice for this problem, since unlike regularized logistic regression, there are no finnicky parameters that need tuning for every new opponent. A suitably large number of forests should be able to both make good predictions on opponents with lots of history and avoid over-fitting on opponents with little history. I did the scraping with BeautifulSoup, represented questions using a publicly available sentence embedding library, and got a little script working. A sample output looked like this:

For the next few days, I used these outputs to inform my defensive choices. It was a very confusing time in my life - every morning I would compare the previous day‚Äôs predictions with what my opponent had actually gotten carefully, and then undertake a Kafkaesque struggle to figure out whether the predictions were actually meaningful. There were days when I was completely convinced I had an edge and days where I was completely convinced I had a list of six random numbers.

The sklearn random forest function has some great introspection tools though, and I was able to use these to get a feel for what was going on with the predictions. I looked at the questions that most commonly co-occurred with the each of the new questions in terminal nodes of the forest, since these would theoretically be the questions that most influenced the probabilities for those questions. To my disappointment, they were complete garbage for players with small question histories. For nearly every question, the following question was found to be extremely influential:

Prompted by the 1902 armed intervention of British and German forces in Venezuela to settle debt claims, an amendment to the Monroe Doctrine was issued stating that only the United States may act as an international police power in the western hemisphere. This supplement is commonly known by what name after the man who issued it in 1904?

Why? Because it contains lots of country names, so any question asking about a ‚ÄúBritish painter‚Äù or ‚ÄúU.S. state‚Äù would register as similar to it. For a question about spheres, a question about pastry puffs was deemed highly relevant, because the sentence embeddings had identified puffs as spherical objects. Trying more examples gave ever more weird connections, false alarms, and general failures to separate the chaff from the wheat. There were some cases where questions were correctly flagged as informative, especially in players with extensive histories, but for players with limited history, the predictions were based on a functionally random sample of past questions.

3. The Case for Transparency

Unfortunately, the problems described above could not be overcome by a different classifier, since they are more a product of the problem structure and choice of embedding. They exist because, in some cases, there really are no questions in the history similar enough to the current one to give meaningful information, and in other cases there are questions that appear similar to the current one, but are different in subtle and algorithmically imperceptible ways that make them useless. Any classification algorithm tries to find relevant questions whether or not they exist, and when they don‚Äôt, it turns up nonsense. So really, the best you can do is make it clear what information went into the predictions, and then place stock in the predictions based on judgement of that information. Once you start thinking in this direction though, the prediction algorithm starts to seem redundant: if you‚Äôre going to look at the questions anyway, why are you relying on an algorithm to make a judgement from them?

To balance my judgement with an algorithm, I settled on the following workflow. I scrape my opponent‚Äôs history, and compute both sentence embeddings and tf-idf embeddings. Then, I use both of these to find nearest neighbors for the current questions. I format and output these to a PDF, and as a sort of half-hearted prediction, note the proportion that were answered correctly. One way to think about this is that there‚Äôs still a (nearest-neighbor) classifier in the picture, and it‚Äôs still spitting out predictions, but those predictions have been relegated to the edge of the frame, leaving the focus on the training data that informed them. Here‚Äôs a sample output for a player with sparse history:

And another sample output on the same question for a player with dense history:

The point is that you can see there is little useful history in the former and plenty in the latter; in both cases, you can see whatever useful history there is.

I‚Äôm always wary of extracting excessively broad lessons from single instances, but this whole project gave me the strong sense of being taught a lesson. Why was I so eager to have list of probabilities? Why did I expect that I could make those probabilities be consistently meaningful? I was aware of all the issues I listed above, and I still thought that the right mix of modeling and magic would give me the answers I wanted. Before I poked around and saw how meaningless the numbers really were, it never even occurred to me that it might be worth contextualizing them. Wary though I am, I think the lesson is that forcing models to offer some kind of epistemic status on their predictions can make those predictions far more useful and far less misleading.

entry.title: Sabermetrics, but for Quizbowl
entry.content:
Quizbowl, which I compete in at UChicago, is like Jeopardy, but with teams. Each team has four players, and whichever team buzzes in first and answers a tossup question correctly gets points, as well as the exclusive chance to answer some bonus questions for more points. After a fixed number of questions, the team with the most points wins. Many efforts are made to reduce the variance of this process, like constructing questions to reward more knowledgable teams and balancing different categories of question in every match, but there are still plenty of surprises over the course of a season.

Quizbowlers are quite caught up in all this - trying to figure out which teams are better than others, which players are better than others, and what to expect from a given match or tournament. To this end, there‚Äôs been a recent trend of collecting extremely detailed data from tournaments, specifically the exact point at where every single player buzzed on every single question. This post tries to use that data from a specific tournament to give concrete predictions about matches. That is, how likely is it that any one team will beat another?

For one team to beat another, they have to score more points than them. Points are scored by getting tossups and getting bonuses. For tossups, we have the buzzpoint information. For bonuses, we have the average number of points a team got across all bonuses. So we can decide which team wins a match by deciding how many tossups each will get, giving them points for all of those, as well as their average number of bonus points for each tossup, and comparing scores.

For a team to get a tossup, they have to buzz in before the other team and answer correctly. This means the object we need to model is the distribution of a team‚Äôs buzzpoints, so that we can compare these between teams and determine who buzzed first.

1. The Distribution of Buzzpoints

I took a non-parametric approach to modeling the distribution of buzzpoints, treating it as coming from a Dirichlet process, which is a distribution over distributions that can be updated based on observations. The idea is that, given a team I know nothing about, I have a baseline belief about the distribution of their distribution of buzzpoints and a measure of strength in that belief. Then, as I observe them buzzing on questions, I perform a Bayesian update on that distribution over distributions, and use the posterior mean as an estimate of the distribution of the team‚Äôs buzzpoints. This is a little abstract, but essentially, instead of updating a single probability based on evidence as we do in standard Bayesian analysis, we‚Äôre updating a collection of probabilities in the form of a distribution based on evidence.

More formally, my initial belief of a team‚Äôs buzzzpoint distribution is a DP(3,F)\text{DP}(3, F) where FF is the distribution function F(x)=x2F(x)=x^2, since this corresponds to a linear density and thus matches the idea that quizbowl questions get easier as they progress. The choice of Œ±=3\alpha=3 is fairly arbitrary, but varying it did not significantly affect results. After observing nn buzzes with empirical distribution FnF_n, we update our belief to a DP(n+3,nn+3Fn+3n+3F),\text{DP}\left(n+3, \frac{n}{n+3}F_n+\frac{3}{n+3}F\right), which has mean nn+3Fn+3n+3F.\frac{n}{n+3}F_n+\frac{3}{n+3}F. This posterior mean is a mixture distribution, both components of which can easily be sampled from.

The upshot of all of this is that, given two teams, we can sample a sequence of buzzpoints for each, and decide who would get each question by comparing those buzzpoints.

Some thorny details to worry about: where a team buzzes on a tossup is highly dependent on the subject being asked about. For example, a team might be excellent at literature but abysmal at current events. This means that you might be updating a distribution of literature buzzpoints based on a current events question, which is obviously the wrong thing to do. The fix here is to keep a separate distribution for every category, and make the appropriate number of draws from each category when simulating a match.

Another issue is that teams sometimes buzz first, but answer incorrectly. The way to handle this is to keep track of the rate at which a team does this in each category, and then have them buzz first but lose the tossup anyway at that rate. Relatedly, not every team buzzes on every tossup, and some tossups are not answered at all. We can handle this similarly, by keeping track of the rate at which a team buzzes on tossups in a category, and drawing a buzz at that same rate.

2. A Case Study

To recap, our process for simulating a match between two teams is:

  1. Determine the posterior distribution of buzzpoints in each category for both teams by updating a Dirichlet process prior based on observed buzzes
  2. In each category, have the teams ‚Äúplay‚Äù as many questions of that category as there are in a match. Playing a tossup here consists of doing the following for both teams:
    1. Having them buzz with probability given by the number of questions they buzzed on in this category divided by the number of questions they heard in this category
    2. If they buzz, determine the point at which they buzz by sampling from the posterior
    3. Have them answer wrong with probability given by the number of questions they answered wrong on in this category divided by the number of questions they buzzed on in this category
    4. Give the team that buzzed first correctly, if there was one, points for answering correctly and penalize the other team if they answered incorrectly
    5. Give the team that buzzed first correctly their average number of bonus points
  3. Aggregate all the points assigned across all questions, and compare to determine a winner

I ran this on real data, from a tournament hosted at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign that had twenty-five teams. For each pair of teams, I simulated one hundred matches between them, and kept track of how many they won. Compiling all of this gives the following picture, in which each entry is the probability that Team 2 beats Team 1:

Ideally, the next steps from here would be to a. make predictions in advance of tournaments to see how well calibrated these probabilities are and b. do this for more teams over the course of an entire season, and then use the data to try and forecast the results of major national tournaments. I‚Äôm not sure either of these will actually materialize due to various tricky details, but I definitely think this is a good approach to the problem that can give interesting insights.

entry.title: The 'New' Taylor Swift: A Study
entry.content:
For the first time in three years, Taylor Swift is releasing new music, and at least according to her, it‚Äôs supposed to be¬†new music. In her own words, the old Taylor is dead. This post takes a look at all of her music to date and tries to figure out (with help from the Spotify API and some lyrics scraping) how it‚Äôs changed over time, and whether or not the two singles from her new album really represent a radical departure from her earlier stuff.

Before we look at anything, I should be clear about exactly which songs are under consideration here: everything from the albums Taylor Swift, Fearless, Speak Now, Red, and 1989 as well as the two singles from Reputation that have been released (‚ÄúLook What You Made Me Do‚Äù and ‚ÄúReady For It‚Äù). The deluxe tracks from all those albums are fair game as well, except the ones from Taylor Swift because they‚Äôre not on Spotify. What‚Äôs not fair game is the music from her holiday collection or anything she recorded for a soundtrack (including ‚ÄúI Don‚Äôt Wanna Live Forever.‚Äù) These lines are somewhat arbitrary, but I think the albums are the best benchmarks of her evolution since they‚Äôre polished final products. Taken together, this gives 86 songs under consideration.

Code for all of this can be found here.

1. The Music

For this section, we consider only the sound of the songs, ignoring any lyrics. We quantify the sound of songs using Spotify‚Äôs audio features. Specifically, I took what they call the acousticness, danceability, energy, liveness, loudness, tempo, and valence for each song.

1.1. Records and Rankings

The first thing I did was look at the extremes: the songs that had the highest and lowest value for each of the seven features. I thought that if one of the new singles showed up on this list, it would be a sign that her music was moving in a new direction.

Feature ¬†Lowest Highest
Acousticness State Of Grace Never Grow Up
Danceability This Love Hey Stephen
Energy Never Grow Up Haunted
Liveness The Story Of Us Better Than Revenge
Valence This Love Shake It Off
Tempo This Love Long Live
Loudness Sad Beautiful Tragic Picture To Burn

But neither of them did. The two things I did notice were that ‚ÄúThis Love‚Äù is clearly out there for her and that the only song on here that was a big hit was ‚ÄúShake It Off.‚Äù Maybe extremes aren‚Äôt good for chart success.

The other thing I did right off the bat was, for each feature, rank each of her full albums by the average value for that feature. This doesn‚Äôt say anything about her new music, but does give some sense of how she‚Äôs changed in the past.

Rank ¬†Acousticness Danceability Energy Liveness
1 Speak Now 1989 1989 Speak Now
2 Taylor Swift Red Speak Now Taylor Swift
3 Fearless Fearless Taylor Swift Fearless
4 1989 Speak Now Fearless 1989
5 Red Taylor Swift Red Red
Rank ¬†Valence Tempo Loudness
1 Red Taylor Swift Speak Now
2 1989 Speak Now Taylor Swift
3 Taylor Swift 1989 Fearless
4 Speak Now Fearless 1989
5 Fearless Red Red

What really stood out to me here was that Red and 1989 nearly always appeared next to each other, with two exceptions: tempo, where they were separated by Fearless, and Energy, where they appeared on opposite ends of the list! So there‚Äôs something going on here where Red and 1989 are very similar, but different in some key way (a way that‚Äôs captured by the energy feature).

Also, in the acousticness and liveness features, the albums generally go from old to new, which is to be expected since her music became more manufactured over time.

1.2. Visualization

To get a feel for the data set as a whole, I found a two-dimensional representation using t-SNE. Here‚Äôs a plot (with song names truncated at 15 characters to improve readability):

That plot is pretty tough to read even with the truncation, so¬†here‚Äôs a PDF that should be more accessible, especially if you zoom in.

In this graph, you can clearly see that 1989 is her most consistent album (there‚Äôs 10 songs in a relatively small area), followed by Red. Her first album on the other hand is all over the place. So, interpreted with some generosity, the graph shows her developing a sense of style over time.

Looking more closely at the area 1989 is concentrated in, I noticed two things. One is that this area also contains a lot of her big hits, like ‚ÄúYou Belong With Me,‚Äù ‚ÄúWe Are Never Ever Getting Back Together‚Äù and ‚ÄúMine.‚Äù But more notably, it also contains both of the new singles! In two dimensions, Taylor Swift‚Äôs new music is indistinguishable from her old music.

1.3 Clustering

To make concrete the notions of clusters in the previous section, I did some clustering. Specifically, I ran k-means on the seven dimensional points and then visualized the results in a plot similar to the previous ones. I chose to look at 2 and 5 clusters, hoping that they would correspond to the old Taylor/new Taylor and her 5 full albums, respectively.

The two clusters respect the structure in the visualization almost exactly:

Here‚Äôs the PDF. What‚Äôs more important is how this clustering interacts with the albums, which can be seen in this graph:

This isn‚Äôt too informative. We‚Äôd hope that one of the clusters increases steadily from album to album, but the ratios seem to be roughly constant. Let‚Äôs recreate these same two graphs with 5 clusters:

Again,¬†the PDF. These graphs tell a much more interesting story: the first three albums are acoustically scattershot, drawing roughly equally from all the clusters. Then, in Red, she seems to split, toying equally with clusters 0 and 1. Between the two of them, it‚Äôs cluster 1 that wins out, and forms the bulk of 1989, with some small appearances from the others. And (as expected based on our earlier observations), the songs so far from Reputation also fit into cluster 5, making them nothing too new.

It‚Äôs worth taking a second to translate back from ‚Äúclusters‚Äù to more meaningful terms. Looking at the scatter plot, cluster 0 seems to correspond to upbeat pop songs (like ‚ÄúRed‚Äù and ‚ÄúShake It Off‚Äù) while cluster 1 has slower, mellower, songs (like ‚ÄúThe Lucky One‚Äù and ‚ÄúTeardrops on My Guitar‚Äù). And on Red, all of the hit songs were from cluster 0, not cluster 1, maybe explaining her decision to switch over for her next album.

(The other clusters are harder to interpret, but if you figure anything out, let me know!)

2. The Lyrics

As any avid Taylor Swift fan knows though, the real meat of her songs is in the lyrics, so I turned to those next. Thankfully, most of the scraping work had¬†already been done, so I just piggy-backed off that.

2.1. Word Clouds

I started by making word clouds for each of her full albums, as shown in the margin, just because it was easy and cute. They‚Äôre shown in the margin.

2.2. Topic Models

For more substantive analysis, I fit a topic model to the collection of lyrics. I tried latent Dirichlet allocation and non-negative matrix factorization, with the latter giving better results. Somewhat arbitrarily, I fit models with 5 topics. Here is, for each of the 5 topics the model found, the top 20 words:

  • Topic #1: love beautiful cause back baby time say way everything one home take eyes smile feel right better could little well
  • Topic #2: come back movie would gone sinks york miss could figured leave today spelling guess feeling dream new somethings somehow id
  • Topic #3: stay mad hey palm time lock quite want easy lovin hand grow funny late people let beautiful say best well
  • Topic #4: ever ooh talk together getting 22 friends grow back telling yeah nights feels alright mean called remember night used one
  • Topic #5: girl thats works trying want strong alone ever everybody worse yeah knows forever goes wait heart would place get rain

These aren‚Äôt too easy to make sense of, so let‚Äôs bring in some visualizations. First, treating the percentage contribution of each topic to a song as a feature, I used t-SNE to visualize the songs again:

Another tough to read plot, so here‚Äôs¬†the PDF. The relatively clusters are pretty promising, as is the fact that 1989 is again the most tightly clustered album - it‚Äôs both acoustically and thematically unified. The big swath through the bottom has a lot of canonical Taylor Swift love songs (‚ÄúFifteen‚Äù and ‚ÄúSpeak Now‚Äù for example) that definitely belong together, but it‚Äôs not clear why something like ‚ÄúThe Story of Us‚Äù was pushed off to the other cluster, since it‚Äôs clearly a love song as well.

But it turns out that this plot is a little misleading. If we recolor it by dominant topic (i.e.¬†a songs color is determined by the topic that contributes most heavily to it), we get a different story:

(The PDF.) Now it‚Äôs clear that (as many people correctly conclude without any analysis at all) nearly all of her songs are predominantly love songs drawing from Topic 1, and the clusters found by t-SNE are mostly artificial.

It‚Äôs interesting to look at the songs that aren‚Äôt dominated by this topic. A couple of them are clearly not love songs (‚ÄúWelcome to New York‚Äù and ‚Äú22‚Äù) but some are clearly love songs that the model misinterpreted. For example, the scatter plot suggests that the model put ‚ÄúStay Stay Stay‚Äù and ‚ÄúAll You Had To Do Was Stay‚Äù together into a topic of songs about staying, and looking at the key words from the topic confirms this.

Similarly, topic 5 picked up on the word ‚Äúgirl‚Äù in both ‚ÄúHow You Get The Girl‚Äù and ‚ÄúGirl At Home,‚Äù as well as a line from the chorus of ‚ÄúA Place In This World‚Äù and thrust those together.

None of these other topics picked up on the new singles though. They are, at least according to the model, standard Taylor Swift songs.

I had hoped that the model would be able to separate, for example, songs about falling in love and songs about breaking up, but some combination of short songs and non-distinctive vocabulary prevents this from happening.

For one last graph, I plotted the topic composition across albums:

Obviously this graph is a little suspect because of the issues I mentioned above, but it does suggest that the canonical ‚ÄúTaylor Swift love song‚Äù became significantly less important to her work as she aged, in parallel with her shift toward more pop music.

3. Conclusion

Based on both the audio and lyrics of her songs, there‚Äôs a clear pivot of some kind in Taylor Swift‚Äôs music as she moved away from her country roots. But there‚Äôs no reason to believe that that shift continues in her new work, which is extremely similar to 1989. Contrary to what she‚Äôd have us believe, the old Taylor isn‚Äôt dead at all.

  3. If EE is the finite union of closed cubes with disjoint interior, then œáE‚àà‚Ñ±\chi_E\in\mathcal{F}.

    Such an open set EE can be written as the countable union of almost disjoint (i.e.¬†their intersection is null) closed cubes QjQ_j, so we define E=‚ãÉj=1‚àûQjandfk=‚àëj=1kœáQj.E=\bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty} Q_j\quad\text{and}\quad f_k=\sum_{j=1}^k \chi_{Q_j}.     Because a null set EE is measurable, we can find a GŒ¥G_{\delta} set G‚äÉEG\supset E such that Œº(G)=0\mu(G)=0.
