This means that Œº(Gy)=0\mu(G^y)=0 and Ey‚äÇGyE^y\subset G^y, so we have that Œº(Ey)=0\mu(E^y)=0 for almost every yy, and so ‚à´‚Ñùn(‚à´‚ÑùmœáE(x,y)dx)dy=0‚à´‚ÑùdœáE‚üπœáE‚àà‚Ñ±.\int_{\mathbb{R}^n}\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}^m} \chi_E(x,y)\, dx\right)\, dy =0\int_{\mathbb{R}^d}\chi_E\implies \chi_E\in\mathcal{F}.

  2. If EE is measurable with finite measure, then œáE‚àà‚Ñ±\chi_E\in\mathcal{F}.

    Recall that we can find a GŒ¥G_{\delta} set G‚äÉEG\supset E such that Œº(G\E)=0\mu(G\setminus E)=0, and now writing œáE=œáG‚àíœáG\E\chi_E=\chi_G-\chi_{G\setminus E} and Lemma 2 gives that œáE‚àà‚Ñ±.\chi_E\in\mathcal{F}.

Now, any simple function ff is a linear combination of characteristic functions of measurable sets with finite measure, so Lemma 2 shows that f‚àà‚Ñ±f\in\mathcal{F}.

With these three lemmas in hand, we can prove Fubini‚Äôs theorem.

Proof of Fubini‚Äôs Theorem. Suppose ff is an integrable function. We can write ff as the sum of a positive and negative part, so it is sufficient by Lemma 2 to consider the case where ff is non-negative. Because ff is integrable, there are simple functions fkf_k that converge monotonically to ff. By Lemma 4, each fk‚àà‚Ñ±f_k\in\mathcal{F}, and now Lemma 3 allows us to conclude that f‚àà‚Ñ±f\in\mathcal{F}.

entry.title: The Making of a Chernoff Face
entry.content:
I heard about Chernoff faces a few days ago through a post on Hacker News, and immediately had the same question as several people in the comments: how exactly are the data being mapped to these faces? Surprisingly, I wasn‚Äôt able to find a detailed description anywhere online except in an appendix of Chernoff‚Äôs original paper. That appendix is fairly terse, so this post is meant to be a more clear and explicit explanation of how the faces are made and how they can be interpreted.

1. Chernoff‚Äôs Construction

The specific construction in the original paper considers eighteen variables, x1,‚ãØ,x18x_1,\cdots, x_{18}, and builds a face based on these eighteen numbers. We go through these eighteen parameters, describing the effect each has on the final face.

The first five parameters control the overall shape of the face. Of these, the first three provide the underlying skeleton shown below.

Here, OO is the center of the face. The parameters x1,x2x_1, x_2 (the latter of which is an angle from the horizontal) specify a point PP that is the corner of the face. The reflection of PP across the vertical through OO is the other corner of the face, P‚Ä≤P'. The parameter x3x_3 is the length of the face, and specifies the topmost point UU of the face. The reflection of UU about the horizontal through OO is the lowermost point of the face, LL.

The next two, x4x_4 and x5x_5 provide the overall shape of the face by defining its boundary. That boundary consists of two ellipses: one of these is the ellipse through P‚Ä≤,U,PP', U, P with eccentricity x4x_4 and the other is the ellipse through P‚Ä≤,L,PP', L, P with eccentricity x5x_5.

The next parameter, x6x_6, is the simplest: it gives the length of a vertical line segment through OO that is the nose.

The next three parameters determine the mouth, which is situated using the following geometry:

So x7x_7 is the vertical offset of the center of the mouth. The mouth itself is an arc centered at MM with curvature x8x_8, with a length of x9x_9 radians of the full circle.

Then next six parameters control the eyes. Again, the geometry:

The vertical offset of the eyes is $x_{10}, x11x_{11} is the distance between them, and x15x_{15} is the horizontal offset of the pupils. The picture above shows one eye and one pupil, but everything is reflected about the vertical to be symmetric.

The eyes themselves are ellipses centered at EE (and its reflection across the vertical) that have eccentricity x13x_{13} and are slanted at an angle of x12x_{12} to the horizontal. The parameter x14x_{14} is cryptically described by Chernoff as ‚Äúsize of eyes.‚Äù There‚Äôs no standard way to measure the size of an ellipse in one parameter, so I assume this is something like the sum of the lengths of the major and minor axes.

The final three parameters deal with the eyebrows. The geometry:

The vertical offset of the eyebrows is x16x_{16}. Their length is x18x_{18}, and they are rotated at an angle of x17x_{17}.

Finally, the faces are scaled to have a consistent width and height.

2. Interpretation

Now that we know just how every numerical feature translates to a facial feature, we can interpret the faces. The most natural way to do this is consider the effect of large or small values of each feature, which is done for large values in the table below.

Feature Effect of large value
x1x_1 Face with further corner
x2x_2 Face with corners at larger angle
x3x_3 Longer face
x4x_4 More pointed chin
x5x_5 Broader forehead
x6x_6 Longer nose
x7x_7 Lower mouth
x8x_8 Flatter smile
x9x_9 Wider smile
x10x_{10} Higher eyes
x11x_{11} Further separated eyes
x12x_{12} More slanted eyes
x13x_{13} Narrower eyes
x14x_{14} Larger eyes
x15x_{15} Further separated pupils
x16x_{16} Higher eyebrows
x17x_{17} More slanted eyebrows
x18x_{18} Longer eyebrows

The same table for small values could be made by taking the opposite of each row.

3. An Example

To see our interpretation in practice, we look at the sample faces given by Wikipedia, reproduced below.

The 18 featuresSome features are duplicated to reach the required 18

 used are available in R, and we can plug them into the table above to obtain an interpretive guide:

Feature Effect of large value
Judicial integrity Face with further corner
Demeanor Face with corners at larger angle
Diligence Longer face
Case flow managing More pointed chin
Prompt decisions Broader forehead
Preparation for trial Longer nose
Familiarity with law Lower mouth
Sound oral rulings Flatter smile
Sound written rulings Wider smile
Physical ability Higher eyes
Judicial integrity Further separated eyes
Demeanor More slanted eyes
Diligence Narrower eyes
Case flow managing Larger eyes
Prompt decisions Further separated pupils
Preparation for trial Higher eyebrows
Familiarity with law More slanted eyebrows
Sound oral rulings Longer eyebrows

(A similar table is available in the Wikipedia page for the image, but I tried to phrase things more in terms of how we talk about faces.) Based on this and the previous table, we can do several useful things. One is to quickly pick out extremes - for example, Judge Cohen‚Äôs circular eyes give away his lack of diligence. Judge Bracken is not too diligent either, but at least he is better at case flow managing, as reflected in his larger eyes. Another is to get a feel for the general distribution of a trait. Nearly all of the judges are completely flat-mouthed, telling us that the soundness of their oral rulings is fairly uniform.

One counterintuitive thing about this method is that the ordering of the variables is important. Arranging features so that those measuring similar things are affecting the same portions of the face can allow for higher level interpretations (e.g.¬†happy judges give better rulings), while separating them removes this structure. But the idea at least, of using our sensitivity to facial features to help understand data, is a cute one.

entry.title: Martingale Convergence
entry.content:
Last quarter, I did a DRP on martingales, and at the start of this quarter, gave a short talk on what I learned. Here are the notes from that talk.

1. Conditional Expectation

Definition 1. Suppose (Œ©,‚Ñ±o,‚Ñô)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}_o, \mathbb{P}) is a probability space, ‚Ñ±‚äÇ‚Ñ±o\mathcal{F}\subset \mathcal{F}_o is a sub œÉ\sigma-algebra, and XX is a random variable.

  1. The conditional expectation of XX given ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}, E(X‚à£‚Ñ±)E(X\mid \mathcal{F}), is any ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}-measurable random variable YY such that ‚à´AXd‚Ñô=‚à´AYd‚Ñô for all A‚àà‚Ñ±.\int_A X\, d\mathbb{P}=\int_A Y\, d\mathbb{P}\text{ for all } A\in \mathcal{F}.

  2. If YY is another random variable, then E(X‚à£Y)E(X\mid Y) is defined as E(X‚à£‚Ñ±)E(X\mid \mathcal{F}) where ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F} is the œÉ\sigma-algebra generated by YY.

Fact. The conditional expectation exists, is unique, and is integrable.

Intuitively, we can think of E(X‚à£‚Ñ±)E(X\mid \mathcal{F}) as the best guess of the value of XX given the information available in ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}.

Example 1. Some conditional expectations:

  1. If XX is ‚Ñ±\mathcal{F}-measurable, then E(X‚à£‚Ñ±)=XE(X\mid \mathcal{F})=X.

  2. If XX and YY are independent, then E(X‚à£Y)=E(X)E(X\mid Y)=E(X).

  3. Let X1,‚ãØX_1,\cdots be random variables with mean Œº\mu, and let Sn=X1+‚ãØ+XnS_n=X_1+\cdots+X_n be the partial sums. Then, if m>nm>n, E(Sm‚à£Sn)=E(Xm+‚ãØ+Xn+1+Sn‚à£Sn)=E(Xm‚à£Sn)+‚ãØ+E(Xn+1‚à£Sn)+E(Sn‚à£Sn)=Œº(m‚àín)+Sn.E(S_m\mid S_n)=E(X_m+\cdots+X_{n+1}+S_n\mid S_n)=E(X_m\mid S_n)+\cdots+E(X_{n+1}\mid S_n)+E(S_n\mid S_n)=\mu(m-n)+S_n. The idea is that you know your position at SnS_n, and you take m‚àínm-n steps whose sizes are, on average, Œº\mu, so your best guess for your position is Sn+Œº(m‚àín)S_n+\mu(m-n).

Now we can define martingales.

2. Martingales

A martingale is a model of a fair game.

Definition 2. Consider a filtration (increasing sequence of œÉ\sigma-algebras) ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n and a sequence of random variables XnX_n, each measurable with respect to ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n and integrable. Then, if E(Xn+1‚à£‚Ñ±n)=XnE(X_{n+1}\mid \mathcal{F}_n)=X_n for all nn, we say SnS_n is a martingale.

Example 2. Let X1,‚ãØX_1,\cdots be random variables that take only the values ‚àí1-1 and 11 with probability 1/21/2 each. Then Sn=X1+‚ãØ+XnS_n=X_1+\cdots+ X_n is a martingale, because E(Sn+1‚à£Sn)=E(Xn+1+Sn‚à£Sn)=E(Xn+1‚à£Sn)+E(Sn‚à£Sn)=E(Xn+1)+Sn=Sn.E(S_{n+1}\mid S_n)=E(X_{n+1}+S_n\mid S_n)=E(X_{n+1}\mid S_n)+E(S_n\mid S_n)=E(X_{n+1})+S_n=S_n.

Theorem 3. If XnX_n is a martingale with supE(Xn+)<‚àû\sup E(X_n^+)<\infty, then XnX_n converges a.s. to a limit XX with E(|X|)<‚àûE(|X|)<\infty.

I‚Äôll only sketch this proof, because even though the idea is nice, the details are a little annoying. The idea is to set up a way of betting on a martingale, show that you can‚Äôt make money off such a betting system, and then use this to draw conclusions about the martingales behavior.

Definition 4. Let ‚Ñ±n\mathcal{F}_n be a filtration. A sequence HmH_m of random variables is said to be predictable if HmH_m is ‚Ñ±m‚àí1\mathcal{F}_{m-1} measurable for all mm.

That is, the value of HmH_m can always be predicted with certainty at time mm. Then, if we ‚Äúbet‚Äù an amount HmH_m on the martingale XmX_m, our total winnings will be (H‚ãÖX)n=‚àëm=1nHm(Xm‚àíXm‚àí1).(H\cdot X)_n=\sum_{m=1}^n H_m(X_m-X_{m-1}).

If XnX_n is a supermartingale and HnH_n is bounded, then (H‚ãÖX)n(H\cdot X)_n is a supermartingale as well.

Now, fix an interval (a,b)(a,b) and choose HnH_n in the following way: if Xn<aX_n<a, then bet 1, and continue to do so until Xn>bX_n>b. Then bet zero until you fall back below aa, and repeat. Every time you go from below aa to above bb, you will make a profit of at least (b‚àía)(b-a). Let UnU_n be the number of these upcrossings that occur. Then, you can use the previous fact, together with the bound on supE(Xn+)\sup E(X_n^+), to show that the number of these upcrossings is finite with probability 1. Since this is true for arbitrary (a,b)(a,b), the XnX_n must converge.

Proposition 5. Let XnX_n be a sequence of random variables such that P(Xn=1)=P(Xn=‚àí1)=12.P(X_n=1)=P(X_n=-1)=\frac{1}{2}. Then ‚àëj=1‚àûXjj{\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \frac{X_j}{j}} converges with probability 1.

Proof. Let Sn=‚àëj=1nXjj.{S_n=\sum_{j=1}^n\frac{X_j}{j}}. It‚Äôs easy to check that SnS_n is a martingale, and that E(Sn)E(S_n) is bounded (in fact, it‚Äôs always 0), so the SnS_n converge almost surely. Thus the random harmonic series converges almost surely.
